{{other people | Paul Ehrlich}} {{pp-pc1}} {{Infobox scientist | birth_name = Paul Ralph Ehrlich | image = Paul Ehrlich - 1974.jpg | caption = Ehrlich in 1974. | birth_date = {{birth date and age | 1932 | 05 | 29}} | birth_place = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | residence = Stanford, California | nationality = American | field = {{unbulleted list | [[Entomology]] | [[Population studies]]}} | work_institutions = [[Stanford University]] | alma_mater = {{nowrap | {{unbulleted list | [[University of Pennsylvania]] {{small | ([[Bachelor of Arts|AB]])}} | [[University of Kansas]] {{small | (MA, PhD)}} }}}} | doctoral_advisor = [[Charles Duncan Michener|C. D. Michener]] | doctoral_students = | thesis_title = The Morphology, Phylogeny and Higher Classification of the Butterflies (Lepidoptera: Papilionoidea) | thesis_year = 1957 | thesis_url = http://hdl.handle.net/1808/7853 | known_for = ''[[The Population Bomb]]'' | prizes = {{unbulleted list | [[Crafoord Prize]] {{small | (1990)}} | {{raise | 0.4em | {{nowrap |
[[The Heinz Awards|The Heinz Awards]], Environment (Paul and Anne Ehrlich (1995)
[[Tyler Prize for Environmental Achievement]] (1998)
[[Fellow of the Royal Society]] {{small | (2012)}}[http://royalsociety.org/people/paul-ehrlich/ Professor Paul R. Ehrlich ForMemRS], The Royal Society, retrieved September 26, 2012.}}}} }}2013 [[BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Awards|BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award]] | spouse = {{nowrap | [[Anne H. Ehrlich]] {{small | (married 1954)}}}} | children = Lisa Marie }} '''Paul Ralph Ehrlich''' (born May 29, 1932) is an [[United States|American]] biologist, best known for his warnings about the consequences of [[population growth]] and limited resources.{{cite web | last=Mieszkowski | first=Katharine | url=http://www.salon.com/news/environment/feature/2008/09/17/population_control | title=Do we need population control? | publisher=Salon.com | date=2008-09-17 | accessdate=2012-09-27}} He is the Bing Professor of [[Population Studies]] of the Department of Biology of [[Stanford University]] and president of Stanford's Center for [[Conservation biology|Conservation Biology]]. Ehrlich became well known for his controversial 1968 book ''[[The Population Bomb]]'', which asserted that the world's human population would soon increase to the point where mass starvation ensued. Among the solutions he suggested in that book was [[population control]], to be used in his opinion if voluntary methods were to fail. Ehrlich has been criticized for his opinions; for example, [[Ronald Bailey]] termed Ehrlich an "irrepressible doomster". However, Carl Haub observed that Ehrlich's warnings had encouraged governments to change their policies to avert disaster. Ehrlich has acknowledged that some of what he predicted has not occurred, but maintains that his predictions about disease and climate change were essentially correct, and that [[human overpopulation]] is a major problem. ==Early life, education, and academic career== [[File:Paul R Ehrlich.png|thumb|Ehrlich circa 2010]] Ehrlich was born in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], the son of William Ehrlich and Ruth (Rosenberg) Ehrlich,{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oHYD-XUiSBEC&pg=PA318&lpg=PA318| title=Leaders from the 1960s: A Biographical Sourcebook of American Activism | publisher=Greenwood Press, 1994 | page=318 |}} [[liberal Judaism|liberal]] [[American Jews|Jews]].{{cite book | url=https://books.google.co.il/books?id=bjooDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA260&lpg=PA260| title=Inherit the Holy Mountain: Religion and the Rise of American Environmentalism | publisher=Oxford University Press, 2015 | page=260 |}} His father was a shirt salesman, his mother a [[Greek language|Greek]] and [[Latin]] scholar{{cite web | title=PAUL EHRLICH | url=http://www.abc.net.au/rn/latenightlive/stories/2009/2747139.htm | work=Radio National | publisher=ABC | accessdate=4 March 2013 | author=Phillip Adams | author2=Kate MacDonald | date=19 November 2009}} and public school teacher. Ehrlich's mother's Reform-Jewish German ancestors arrived in the United States in the 1840s, and his paternal grandparents immigrated there later from the Galician and Romanian part of the Austrian Empire. During his childhood his family moved to [[Maplewood, New Jersey]], where he attended high school. Ehrlich earned a bachelor's degree in [[zoology]] from the [[University of Pennsylvania]] in 1953, an M.A. from the [[University of Kansas]] in 1955, and a Ph.D. from the University of Kansas in 1957, supervised by the prominent [[bee]] researcher [[Charles Duncan Michener]] (the title of his dissertation: "The Morphology, Phylogeny and Higher Classification of the Butterflies (Lepidoptera: Papilionoidea)").Ehrlich, Paul R., "[http://hdl.handle.net/1808/7853 The Morphology, Phylogeny and Higher Classification of the Butterflies (Lepidoptera: Papilionoidea)]," Ph.D. dissertation, University of Kansas, May 1957. During his studies he participated with surveys of [[insect]]s in the areas of the [[Bering Sea]] and [[Canada|Canadian]] [[Arctic]], and then with a [[National Institutes of Health]] fellowship, investigated the genetics and behavior of parasitic [[mite]]s. In 1959 he joined the faculty at [[Stanford University]], being promoted to professor of [[biology]] in 1966. By training he is an [[entomologist]] specializing in [[Lepidoptera]] (butterflies); he published a major paper about the evolution of plants and insects.{{cite journal | last1=Ehrlich | first1=Paul R. | last2=Raven | first2=Peter H. | year=1964 | title=Butterflies and Plants: A Study in Coevolution | journal=Evolution | volume=18 | issue=4 | pages=586–608 | doi=10.2307/2406212}} He was appointed to the Bing Professorship in 1977.{{cite web | title=PAUL R. EHRLICH | url=http://www.stanford.edu/group/CCB/Staff/Paul%20EhrlichCV.PDF | work=Paul R. Ehrlich Resume | publisher=Stanford University | accessdate=4 March 2013 | author=Paul R. Ehrlich | format=PDF | year=2001}}Lewis, J. "Biologist Paul R. Ehrlich. Six billion and counting". ''Scientific American'' October 2000, pages 30, 32. He is president of the Center for Conservation Biology at Stanford University.{{cite web | title=Paul R. Ehrlich | url=http://www.stanford.edu/group/CCB/cgi-bin/ccb/content/paul-r-ehrlich | work=Center for Conservation Biology – Department of Biology | publisher=Stanford University | accessdate=4 March 2013 | year=2013}} He is a fellow of the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]], the [[United States National Academy of Sciences]], the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] and the [[American Philosophical Society]]. ==Overpopulation debate== {{further|Human overpopulation}} [[File:Population curve.svg|thumb|300px | The case for a population bomb: human population has dramatically increased.]] [[File:WorldPopGrowth.png|thumb|The case against a population bomb: Since the 1950s population growth rate has decreased, and is projected to decline further.]] A lecture that Ehrlich gave on the topic of overpopulation at the [[Commonwealth Club of California]] was broadcast by radio in April 1967.{{cite web | title=Story: Paul Ehrlich, the Vindication of a Public Scholar. | url=http://spot.us/pitches/135-paul-ehrlich-the-vindication-of-a-public-scholar/story | work=Spot.us (first published by The Earth Island Journal) | publisher=American Public Media | accessdate=4 March 2013 | author=Tom Turner | year=2011}} The success of the lecture caused further publicity, and the suggestion from [[David Brower]] the executive director of the environmentalist [[Sierra Club]], and [[Ian Ballantine]] of [[Ballantine Books]] to write a book concerning the topic. Ehrlich and his wife, [[Anne Ehrlich]], collaborated on the book, ''[[The Population Bomb]]'', but the publisher insisted that a single author be credited.{{cite journal | author1=Paul R. Ehrlich | author2=Anne H. Ehrlich | title=The Population Bomb Revisited | url=http://www.populationmedia.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/Population-Bomb-Revisited-Paul-Ehrlich-20096.pdf | journal=Electronic Journal of Sustainable Development | year=2009 | volume= 1 | issue = 3 | pages=63–71 | accessdate=September 26, 2012}} Although Ehrlich was not the first to warn about population issues – concern had been widespread during the 1950s and 1960s – his charismatic and media-savvy methods helped publicize the topic.{{cite book | title=Future Babble: Why Expert Predictions Fail – and Why We Believe Them Anyway | author=Dan Gardner | publisher=McClelland and Stewart | year=2010 | location=Toronto}} ===Writings=== ====''The Population Bomb'' (1968)==== The original edition of ''The Population Bomb'' began with this statement: "The battle to feed all of humanity is over. In the 1970s hundreds of millions of people will starve to death in spite of any crash programs embarked upon now. At this late date nothing can prevent a substantial increase in the world death rate ..."{{cite book | author=Ehrlich, Paul R. | title=The Population Bomb | publisher=Ballantine Books | year=1968 }} Ehrlich argued that the human population was too great, and that while the extent of disaster could be mitigated, humanity could not prevent severe famines, the spread of disease, social unrest, and other negative consequences of overpopulation. By the end of the 1970s, this prediction proved to be incorrect. However, he continued to argue that societies must take strong action to decrease population growth in order to mitigate future disasters, both ecological and social. In the book Ehrlich presented a number of "scenarios" detailing possible future events, some of which have been used as examples of errors in the years since. Of these scenarios, Ehrlich has said that although, "we clearly stated that they were not predictions and that 'we can be sure that none of them will come true as stated,’ (p. 72) – their failure to occur is often cited as a failure of prediction. In honesty, the scenarios were way off, especially in their timing (we underestimated the resilience of the world system). But they did deal with future issues that people in 1968 should have been thinking about." Ehrlich further states that he still endorses the main thesis of the book, and that its message is as apt now as it was in 1968. Ehrlich's opinions have evolved over time, and he has proposed different solutions to the [[Human overpopulation|problem of overpopulation]]. In ''Population Bomb'' he wrote, "We must have [[population control]] at home, hopefully through a system of incentives and penalties, but by compulsion if voluntary methods fail. We must use our political power to push other countries into programs which combine agricultural development and population control." Voluntary measures he has endorsed include the easiest possible availability of [[birth control]] and [[abortion]]. In 1967 he had expressed his belief that aid should only be given to those countries that were not considered to be "hopeless" to feed their own populations.{{cite book | last1=Lomborg | first1=Bjørn | title=[[The Skeptical Environmentalist|The skeptical environmentalist : measuring the real state of the world]] | date=2002 | publisher=Cambridge Univ. Press | location=Cambridge | isbn=978-0-521-01068-9 | page=350 | quote=In 1967 Paul Ehrlich predicted that the world was headed for massive starvation. In order to limit the extent of this, he believed – reasonably enough given his point of view – that aid should be given only to those countries that would have a chance to make it through. According to Ehrlich, India was not among them. We must "announce that we will no longer send emergency aid to countries such as India where sober analysis shows a hopeless imbalance between food production and population . . . Our inadequate aid ought to be reserved for those which can survive."}} ====''The Population Explosion'' (1990)==== In their sequel to ''The Population Bomb'', the Ehrlichs wrote about how the world's growing population dwarfs the Earth's capacity to sustain current living standards. The book calls for action to confront population growth and the ensuing crisis:{{cite book | last1=Ehrlich | first1=Paul R. | last2=Ehrlich | first2=Anne H. | title=The population explosion | date=1990 | publisher=Hutchinson | location=London | isbn=0091745519 | pages=39–40 | url=http://www.ditext.com/ehrlich/title.html | accessdate=20 July 2014 }} {{quote | When is an area overpopulated? When its population can't be maintained without rapidly depleting nonrenewable resources [39] (or converting renewable resources into nonrenewable ones) and without degrading the capacity of the environment to support the population. In short, if the long-term carrying capacity of an area is clearly being degraded by its current human occupants, that area is overpopulated.}} ====''Optimum Human Population Size'' (1994) ==== In this paper, the Ehrlichs discuss the [[optimum population|'optimal size' for human population]], given current technological realities. They refer to establishing "social policies to influence fertility rates."Daily, Gretchen C.; Ehrlich, Anne H. and Ehrlich, Paul R. ''[http://dieoff.org/page99.htm Optimum Human Population Size]''. Population and Environment: A Journal of Interdisciplinary Studies Volume 15, Number 6, July 1994 01994 Human Sciences Press. [[File:Paul R. Ehrlich 2008.jpg|thumb|Ehrlich speaking in 2008]] ===After 2000=== During a 2004 interview, Ehrlich answered questions about the predictions he made in ''The Population Bomb''. He acknowledged that some of what he had published had not occurred, but reaffirmed his basic opinion that overpopulation is a major problem. He noted that, "Fifty-eight academies of science said that same thing in 1994, as did the world scientists' warning to humanity in the same year. My view has become depressingly mainline!"{{cite web | title=When Paul's Said and Done | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041115081108/http://www.grist.org/comments/interactivist/2004/08/09/ehrlich/index1.html | publisher=Grist Magazine | accessdate=24 Sep 2015 | author=Ehrlich, Paul | url=http://www.grist.org/comments/interactivist/2004/08/09/ehrlich/index1.html | archivedate=15 November 2004 | date=13 August 2004 |quote="Some things I predicted have not come to pass."}} Ehrlich also stated that 600 million people were very hungry, billions were under-nourished, and that his predictions about disease and climate change were essentially correct. Retrospectively, Ehrlich believes that ''The Population Bomb'' was "way too optimistic". In a 2008 discussion hosted by the website ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]'', Paul Ehrlich has become more critical of the United States specifically, claiming that it should control its population and consumption as an example to the rest of the world. He has disavowed some of what he said in ''The Population Bomb''. He still thinks that governments should discourage people from having more than two children, suggesting, for example a greater tax rate for larger families.{{cite web | publisher=Salon.com | url=http://www.salon.com/2008/09/17/population_control/ | title=Do we need population control? | author=Katharine Mieszkowski | date=17 Sep 2008 }} In 2011, as the world's population passed the seven billion mark Ehrlich has argued that the next two billion people on Earth would cause more damage than the previous two billion because we are now increasingly having to resort to using more marginal and environmentally damaging resources.{{cite news | last=Hall | first=Eleanor | title=Population analyst warns of catastrophe | url=http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/content/2011/s3351962.htm | accessdate=31 October 2011 | newspaper=The World Today | date=31 October 2011}} As of 2013, Ehrlich continues to perform policy research concerning population and resource issues, with an emphasis upon [[endangered species]], [[cultural evolution]], [[environmental ethics]], and the preservation of [[genetics|genetic]] resources. Along with Dr. Gretchen Daily, he has performed work in countryside [[biogeography]]; that is, the study of making human-disturbed areas hospitable to [[biodiversity]]. His research group at Stanford University examines extensively natural populations of the [[Bay checkerspot butterfly]] (''Euphydryas editha bayensis'').{{cite web | url=http://jrbp.stanford.edu/db/projects/project_display.php?project_id=80 | title=Longterm studies of the Bay checkerspot butterfly and feasibility of reintroduction | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060902173022/http://jrbp.stanford.edu/db/projects/project_display.php?project_id=80 | archivedate=2006-09-02 | df= }} The population-related disasters Ehrlich predicted have largely failed to materialize, with population growth rates slowing and new food production technologies increasing the food supply faster than the population.{{cite web | last=Haberman | first=Clyde | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/01/us/the-unrealized-horrors-of-population-explosion.html | title=The Unrealized Horrors of Population Explosion | publisher=The New York Times | date=2015-05-31 | accessdate=2015-05-31}} Ehrlich endorses his general thesis that the human population is too large, posing a direct threat to human survival and the environment of the planet. =={{anchor | Critics}}Reception== [[File:Wheat yields in Least Developed Countries.svg|thumb|280px|Wheat yields have grown rapidly in [[least developed countries]] since 1961.{{cite web | title=Wheat yields are levelling off, even in some developing countries | url=http://environmentalresearchweb.org/cws/article/news/49901 | website=environmentalresearchweb.org}}]] Critics have disputed Ehrlich's main thesis about overpopulation and its effects on the environment and human society, and his solutions, as well as some of his specific predictions made since the late 1960s. One criticism concerns Ehrlich's allegedly alarmist and sensational statements and inaccurate "predictions". [[Ronald Bailey]] of ''[[Reason Magazine]]'' has termed him an "irrepressible doomster ... who, as far as I can tell, has never been right in any of his forecasts of imminent catastrophe." On the first [[Earth Day]] in 1970, he warned that "[i]n ten years all important animal life in the sea will be extinct. Large areas of coastline will have to be evacuated because of the stench of dead fish."{{cite web | title=Cracked Crystal Ball: Environmental Catastrophe Edition | url=http://reason.com/blog/2010/12/30/cracked-crystal-ball-environme | work=reason.com – Free minds and free markets | publisher=Reason Foundation | accessdate=4 March 2013 | author=Ronald Bailey | date=30 December 2010}}{{cite news| title=Eight Botched Environmental Forecasts |url=http://www.foxnews.com/scitech/2010/12/30/botched-environmental-forecasts/ | date=December 30, 2010 | author=Maxim Lott | work=FOX News | accessdate=2015-10-31 | quote="Again, not totally accurate, but I never claimed to predict the future with full accuracy"}} In a 1971 speech, he predicted that: "By the year 2000 the [[United Kingdom]] will be simply a small group of impoverished islands, inhabited by some 70 million hungry people." "If I were a gambler," Professor Ehrlich concluded before boarding an airplane, " I would take even money that [[England]] will not exist in the year 2000." When this scenario did not occur, he responded that "When you predict the future, you get things wrong. How wrong is another question. I would have lost if I had had taken the bet. However, if you [[Demographics of England|look closely at England]], what can I tell you? They're having all kinds of problems, just like everybody else." Ehrlich wrote in ''The Population Bomb'' that, "India couldn't possibly feed two hundred million more people by 1980." Carl Haub of the [[Population Reference Bureau]] has replied that it was precisely the alarmist rhetoric that prevented the catastrophes of which Ehrlich warned. According to Haub "It makes no sense that Ehrlich is now criticized as being alarmist because his dire warnings did not, in the main, come true. But it was because of such warnings from Ehrlich and others that countries took action to avoid potential disaster."{{cite web | author=Haub, Carl | title=In Defense of Paul Ehrlich | url=http://prbblog.org/?p=22 | date= 5 November 2008 | accessdate= 10 February 2011 | work=Behind the Numbers: The PRB blog on population, health, and the environment }} During the 1960s and 70s when Ehrlich made his most alarming warnings, there was a widespread belief among experts that population growth presented an extremely serious threat to the future of human civilization, although differences existed regarding the severity of the situation, and how to decrease it.{{cite news | last=Leonhardt | first=David | title=Lessons From a Famous Bet | url=https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/09/30/lessons-from-a-famous-bet/ | accessdate=24 October 2013 | newspaper=New York Times | date=September 30, 2013}} [[File:Felsoetold Wheat field, Hungary.jpg| thumb | left | 280px | A large increase in global [[Agricultural productivity|food production]] since the 1960s and a slowing of [[population growth]] have, within the current context of continued depletion of [[non-renewable resources]], averted the scale of food shortage, [[famine]] and catastrophe foretold by the Ehrlichs.]] Dan Gardner argues that Ehrlich has been insufficiently forthright in acknowledging errors he made, while being intellectually dishonest or evasive in taking credit for things he claims he got "right". For example, he rarely acknowledges the mistakes he made in predicting material shortages, massive death tolls from starvation (as many as one billion in the publication ''Age of Affluence'') or regarding the disastrous effects on specific countries. Meanwhile, he is happy to claim credit for "predicting" the increase of [[AIDS]] or global warming. However, in the case of disease, Ehrlich had predicted the increase of a disease based on overcrowding, or the weakened immune systems of starving people, so it is "a stretch to see this as forecasting the emergence of AIDS in the 1980s." Similarly, global warming was one of the scenarios that Ehrlich described, so claiming credit for it, while disavowing responsibility for failed scenarios is a [[double standard]]. Gardner believes that Ehrlich is displaying classical signs of [[cognitive dissonance]], and that his failure to acknowledge obvious errors of his own judgement render his current thinking suspect. [[Barry Commoner]] has criticized Ehrlich's 1970 statement that "When you reach a point where you realize further efforts will be futile, you may as well look after yourself and your friends and enjoy what little time you have left. That point for me is 1972."{{cite journal | journal=Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists | author= Barry Commoner | date=May 1972 | title=A Bulletin Dialogue: on "The Closing Circle" — Response | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pwsAAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA17#v=onepage&q&f=false | pages=17–56 }} Gardner has criticized Ehrlich for endorsing the strategies proposed by William and Paul Paddock in their book ''[[Famine 1975!]]''. They had proposed a system of "triage" that would end food aid to "hopeless" countries such as India and Egypt. In ''Population Bomb'', Ehrlich suggests that "there is no rational choice except to adopt some form of the Paddocks' strategy as far as food distribution is concerned." Had this strategy been implemented for countries such as India and Egypt, which were reliant on food aid at that time, they would almost certainly have suffered famines. Instead, both Egypt and India have greatly increased their food production and now feed much larger populations without reliance on food aid. ===Left-wing critics=== Another group of critics, generally of the [[political left]], argues that Ehrlich emphasizes overpopulation too much as a problem in itself instead of distribution of resources. [[Barry Commoner]] argued that Ehrlich emphasized overpopulation too much as the source of environmental problems, and that his proposed solutions were politically unacceptable because of the coercion that they implied, and because they would cost poor people disproportionately. He argued that technological, and above all social development would result in a natural decrease of both population growth and environmental damage.{{cite journal | journal=Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists | author=Barry Commoner | date=May 1972 | title=A Bulletin Dialogue: on "The Closing Circle" — Response | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pwsAAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA17#v=onepage&q&f=false | pages=17–56 | quote=Population control (as distinct from voluntary, self-initiated control of fertility), no matter how disguised, involves some measure of political repression, and would burden the poor nations with the social cost of a situation — overpopulation — which is the current outcome of their previous exploitation, as colonies, by the wealthy nations.}} Ehrlich denies any type of racism, and has argued that if his policy ideas were implemented properly they would not be repressive.{{cite book | title=The Race Bomb | year=1978 | publisher=Ballantine Books | author=Paul Ehrlich | author2=Shirley Feldman }} In a 2018 interview with ''The Guardian'', Ehrlich advocated for an "unprecedented redistribution of wealth" in order to mitigate the problem of [[overconsumption]] of resources by the wealthy, but said "the rich who now run the global system – that hold the annual ‘world destroyer’ meetings in Davos – are unlikely to let it happen."{{cite news |last= Carrington|first=Damian|date=March 22, 2018 |title=Paul Ehrlich: 'Collapse of civilisation is a near certainty within decades'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2018/mar/22/collapse-civilisation-near-certain-decades-population-bomb-paul-ehrlich|work=[[The Guardian]] |location= |access-date=April 4, 2018 }} ===Simon–Ehrlich wager=== {{main | Simon–Ehrlich wager}} [[Julian Simon]], a [[cornucopian]] [[economist]], argued that overpopulation is not a problem in itself, and that humanity will adapt to changing conditions. Simon argued that eventually human creativity will improve living standards, and that most resources were replaceable.{{cite journal | title=Resources, Population, Environment: An Oversupply of False Bad News | journal=Science | volume=208 | date=June 27, 1980 | pages=1431–1437 | issue=4451 | doi=10.1126/science.7384784 | pmid=7384784 | last1=Simon | first1=JL | jstor=1684670}} Simon stated that over hundreds of years, the prices of virtually all commodities have decreased significantly and persistently.{{cite book |title=The End of Doom |author=[[Ronald Bailey]] |date=2015 |publisher=St. Martin's Press |isbn=978-1-250-05767-9 |pages=38, 59 |quote="...nearly all resources in the past were much more expensive than they are today"}} Ehrlich termed Simon the proponent of a "space-age cargo cult" of economists convinced that human creativity and ingenuity would create substitutes for scarce resources and reasserted the idea that population growth was outstripping the earth's supplies of food, fresh water and minerals. This exchange resulted in the [[Simon–Ehrlich wager]], a bet about the trend of prices for resources during a ten-year period that was made with Simon in 1980.{{cite news | last=Tierney | first= John | url= https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/02/magazine/betting-on-the-planet.html?pagewanted=print&src=pm | title= Betting on the Planet | work=The New York Times | date= December 2, 1990 | accessdate=September 26, 2012}} Ehrlich was allowed to choose ten commodities that he predicted would become scarce and thus increase in price. Ehrlich chose mostly metals, and lost the bet, as their average price decreased by about 30% in the next 10 years. Simon and Ehrlich could not agree about the terms of a second bet. ===Ehrlich's response to critics=== Ehrlich has argued that humanity has simply deferred the disaster by the use of more intensive agricultural techniques, such as those introduced during the [[Green Revolution]]. Ehrlich claims that increasing populations and affluence are increasingly stressing the global environment, due to such factors as loss of [[biodiversity]], [[overfishing]], [[global warming]], [[urbanization]], chemical pollution and competition for raw materials.{{cite book | author=Paul Ehrlich | author2=Anne Ehrlich | title=One with Nineveh:politics, consumption, and the human future | publisher=Island Press | year=2004 }} He maintains that due to growing global incomes, reducing consumption and human population is critical to protecting the environment and maintaining living standards, and that current rates of growth are still too great for a sustainable future.{{cite news | title=Paul R. Ehrlich: Saving Earth | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/feb/12/opinion/la-oe-morrison-ehrlich-021211 | accessdate=4 March 2013 | newspaper=Los Angeles Times | date=12 February 2011 | author=Patt Morrison | quote=Consumption is equally important. I'd think the biggest problem is figuring out what to do on consumption. We don't have any consumption condoms.}}{{cite web | title=Still Ticking | url=http://www.the-scientist.com/?articles.view/articleNo/29380/title/Still-Ticking/ | work=The Scientist | publisher=LabX Media Group | accessdate=4 March 2013 | author=Cristina Luiggi | date=1 December 2010}}{{cite journal | last=Ehrlich | first=Paul R. | author2=Ehrlich, Anne H. | journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society | date=March 7, 2013 | volume=280 | series=B | issue=1754 | doi=10.1098/rspb.2012.2845 | url=http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/280/1754/20122845.full | title=Can a collapse of global civilization be avoided? | accessdate=January 27, 2013 | pages=20122845| pmc=3574335 }}   Also see: [http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/280/1767/20131193#ref-1 Comment] by Prof. Michael Kelly, disagreeing with the paper by Ehrlich and Ehrlich; and [http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/280/1767/20131373 response] by the authors.{{cite news | title=Green revolution could still blow up in our face | url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2008/02/02/1201801097280.html | accessdate=4 March 2013 | newspaper=The Age | date=3 February 2008 | author=Colin Fraser | agency=Fairfax Media}} ==Other activities== Ehrlich was one of the initiators of the group [[Population Connection|Zero Population Growth]] (renamed Population Connection) in 1968, along with Richard Bowers and [[Charles Remington]]. In 1971, Ehrlich was elected to the [[Common Cause]] National Governing Board. He and his wife Anne were part of the board of advisers of the [[Federation for American Immigration Reform]] until 2003. He is currently a patron of [[Population Matters]], (formerly known as the Optimum Population Trust).{{cite web | title=Population Matters Patron | url=http://www.populationmatters.org/about/people/patrons/ | website=www.populationmatters.org | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140625195121/http://populationmatters.org/about/people/patrons/ | archivedate=2014-06-25 | df= }} Consistent with his concern about the impact of pollution and in response to a doctoral dissertation by his student Edward Goth III, Ehrlich wrote in 1977 that, “Fluorides have been shown to concentrate in food chains, and evidence suggesting a potential for significant ecological effects is accumulating.”Zelko F. Optimizing nature: Invoking the “natural” in the struggle over water fluoridation. History of Science. 2018; 1–22. Ehrlich has spoken at conferences in Israel on the issue of [[desertification]]. He has argued that "True Zionists should have small families".{{cite web | url=http://www.haaretz.com/weekend/magazine/true-zionists-should-have-small-families-suggests-paul-ehrlich-40-years-after-writing-the-population-bomb.premium-1.483039 | title='True Zionists should have small families' suggests Paul Ehrlich, 40 years after writing 'The Population Bomb'}} ==Personal life== Ehrlich has been married to [[Anne H. Ehrlich]] (born Anne Fitzhugh Howland, 1933) since December 1954; the two are parents to one child, Lisa Marie.{{cite web | url=http://icte.umsl.edu/WEArecipients/ehrlich.html | title=Whitney R. Morgan began his career in [[Fleet Street]] as a writer and editor for several [[tabloid journalism|tabloid]] papers, including ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'', ''[[News of the World]]'', and the ''[[Daily Mirror]]''. In 1994, aged 29, he was appointed editor of the ''News of the World'' by [[Rupert Murdoch]], which made him the youngest editor of a British national newspaper in more than half a century. He later edited the ''Daily Mirror'', and was in charge during the period that the paper was implicated in the [[News International phone hacking scandal|phone hacking scandal]]. In 2011 Morgan denied having ever hacked a phone or "to my knowledge published any story obtained from the hacking of a phone". In 2012 he was heavily criticised in the findings of the [[Leveson Inquiry]], when the chair [[Brian Leveson]] stated that comments made in Morgan's testimony about phone hacking were "utterly unpersuasive" and "clearly prove ... that he was aware that it was taking place in the press as a whole and that he was sufficiently unembarrassed by what was criminal behaviour that he was prepared London Gazette|date=13 September 1966|page=67}} and Gabrielle Georgina Sybille (née Oliver),{{cite web|url=http://website.lineone.net/~hstjw/p29.htm#i1071|first=Hugh|last=Wilding|title=Wildings & Thurleys, Cantophers & McConnells|year=2008}} who raised her son as a [[Catholic Church|Catholic]]. With regard to his religious views, Morgan still identifies as a Catholic due to his mother's influence, and believes in an [[afterlife]], but does not "go to [[Sacrament of Penance|Confession]], probably because it would take me too long".{{cite news |last1=Mance |first1=Henry |title=Piers Morgan on Trump, Twitter and the power of prayer |url=https://www.ft.com/content/eac296be-03fc-11e7-ace0-1ce02ef0def9 |accessdate=30 July 2018 |work=Financial Times |date=15 March 2017}} He has a brother, Jeremy, who is two years older. His father died when Morgan was 11 months old; his mother later married Glynne Pughe-Morgan,Piers Morgan, The Hot Seat: Love, War, and Cable News (2014), p. 5Roy Greenslade, Press Gang: How Newspapers Make Profits from Propaganda (2004), p. 602 a Welsh publican later in the meat distribution business, and he took his stepfather's surname.{{cite news |last=Davies |first=Hunter |author-link=Hunter Davies |date=13 December 1994 |title=From City boy to World leader |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/from-city-boy-to-world-leader-1387335.html |work=[[The Independent]] |accessdate=16 July 2018}} He was at the independent Cumnor House prep school between the ages of seven and 13, then [[Chailey School]], a [[Comprehensive school|comprehensive]] [[secondary school]] in [[Chailey]], near [[Lewes]], [[East Sussex]]. {{Cite news|last1=Naughton|first1=Philippe|last2=Costello|first2=Miles|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/news/the-rhino-in-riot-gear-has-a-way-of-coaxing-out-secrets-3hvp7nw6kt2|title=The rhino in riot gear has a way of coaxing out secrets: PROFILE: Piers Morgan|work=[[The Sunday Times]]|date=6 April 2008|accessdate=16 July 2018}} {{subscription required}} After nine months at [[Lloyd's of London]], Morgan studied [[journalism]] at [[Harlow College]]. Morgan joined the Surrey and South London Newspaper Group in 1985,{{cite web|last=Ortiz|first=Jen|title=SCANDALOUS! 11 Years in the Life of Piers Morgan|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/piers-morgan-hacking-murdoch-bio-2011-7|newspaper=Business Insider|accessdate=11 November 2011}} working as a reporter on the ''South London News'', and the ''Streatham and Tooting News''. ==Press career== ===At the Murdoch titles (1988–1995)=== Morgan began to work as a freelance at ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' in 1988, at this point dropping his [[double-barrelled name]]. He told [[Hunter Davies]] in December 1994 that he was personally recruited by ''Sun'' editor [[Kelvin MacKenzie]] to work on the newspaper's show business column "Bizarre", his first high-profile post. Although he was not a fan of pop music, he was considered skilled at self-publicity and became the column's main writer. "I became the Friend of the Stars, a rampant egomaniac, pictured all the time with famous people – Madonna, Stallone, Bowie, Paul McCartney, hundreds of them. It was shameless, as they didn't know me from Adam", he told Davies. In January 1994, he became editor of the ''[[News of the World]]'' after being appointed to the job by [[Rupert Murdoch]]. Initially an acting editor, he was confirmed in the summer, becoming at 29 the youngest national newspaper editor in more than half a century. He quickly gained notice for his prying, forthright style and lack of sympathy for celebrities' privacy, claiming that they could not manipulate the media to further their own ends without accepting the consequences of a two-way deal. Morgan left this post in 1995 shortly after publishing photographs of [[Victoria Aitken|Catherine Victoria Lockwood]], then wife of [[Charles Spencer, 9th Earl Spencer|Charles, Earl Spencer]], leaving an addictive disorders clinic in Surrey.{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Rhys |date=12 May 1995 |title=Murdoch lashes editor shock |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/murdoch-lashes-editor-shock-1619121.html |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=13 January 2015}} This action ran against the editors' code of conduct,[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/3713857.stm "Profile: Piers Morgan"], BBC News, 14 May 2004 a misdemeanour for which the [[Press Complaints Commission]] upheld a complaint against Morgan. Murdoch was reported as having said that "the boy went too far"Ginny Dougary [http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/arts/books/article2451447.ece "Educating Piers"], ''The Times Magazine'', 7 April 2007. {{subscription}} and publicly distanced himself from the story.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/47847.stm "Earl Spencer loses privacy battle to Europe"], BBC News, 16 January 1998 Fearful of a privacy law action if he had not criticised one of his employees, Murdoch is said to have apologised to Morgan in private.Tom Watson and Martin Hickman [https://books.google.com/books?id=Lel9DjaPgqEC&pg=PT30 ''Dial M for Murdoch: News Corporation and the Corruption of Britain''], London: Penguin, 2012, p. 30Benjamin Wallace [http://nymag.com/news/media/piers-morgan-2011-10/index1.html "Piers Morgan Isn’t Sleeping Well"], ''New York'' (magazine), 9 October 2011 The incident was reported to have contributed to Morgan's decision to leave for the ''Daily Mirror'' editorship.{{cite news |last=Summerskill |first=Ben |author-link=Ben Summerskill |date=1 September 2002 |title=Has Piers now got news for Ian? |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2002/sep/01/pressandpublishing.uknews |newspaper=[[The Observer]] |accessdate=13 January 2015}} Morgan's autobiography ''[[The Insider: The Private Diaries of a Scandalous Decade|The Insider]]'' states that he left the ''News of the World'' for the ''Mirror'' of his own choice. It asserts he was an admirer of former prime minister [[Margaret Thatcher]] for most of her period of office making the appointment surprising as the ''Mirror'' is a Labour supporting title. ===''Daily Mirror'' editor (1995–2004)=== As editor of the ''Daily Mirror'', Morgan was forced to apologise on television for the headline (rendered in upper case) "Achtung Surrender! For You Fritz Ze Euro Championship Is Over" on 25 June 1996, a day before [[England national football team|England]] met [[Germany national football team|Germany]] in a semi-final of the [[1996 European Football Championship|Euro '96]] football championships.{{cite news |last=Maguire |first=Kevin |author-link=Kevin Maguire (journalist) |date=25 February 2002 |title=The New Statesman Profile – Piers Morgan |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/node/142285 |newspaper=[[New Statesman]] |location=London |accessdate=13 January 2015}}{{cite news |last=Byrne |first=Ciar |date=15 May 2004 |title=Piers Morgan: The man with no moral compass who found his destiny in a steadfast opposition to war |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/piers-morgan-the-man-with-no-moral-compass-who-found-his-destiny-in-a-steadfast-opposition-to-war-6169902.html |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=13 January 2015}}George Wilkes and Dominic Wing "The British Press and European Integration: 1948 to 1996", in David Baker, David Seawright (eds.) [https://books.google.com/books?id=MBKbtzPdbhQC&pg=PA202 ''Britain for and Against Europe: British Politics and the Question of European Integration''], Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1998, p. 202{{Cite news |last=Thomsen |first=Ian |date=26 June 1996 |title=Oh, Sorry: Tabloids Lose the Soccer War |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/26/news/26iht-england.t_0.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=3 June 2008}} A £16 million package of investment in the title was rolled out from January, including the dropping of "''Daily''" from the masthead in February,Roy Greenslade ''Press Gang: How Newspapers Make Profits From Propaganda'', London: Pan, 2004 [2003], p. 657 which was later reversed. [[Roy Greenslade]] wrote in August 1999 that Morgan's editorship "has made a huge difference: his enormous enthusiasm, determination and focus is a major plus".Roy Greenslade [https://www.theguardian.com/media/1999/aug/16/mondaymediasection.columnists "Chasing the Sun's tail"], ''The Guardian'', 16 August 1999 Morgan was the subject of an investigation in 2000 after Suzy Jagger wrote an article for ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' revealing that he had bought [[pound sterling|£]]20,000 worth of shares in the computer company [[Viglen]] soon before the ''Mirror'' 's "City Slickers" column tipped Viglen as a good buy.{{cite news|last=Jagger |first=Suzy |title=Mirror editor saw his shares soar after paper tipped company |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/htmlContent.jhtml?html=/archive/2000/02/02/nmir02.html |deadurl=yes |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021122223139/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/htmlContent.jhtml?html=%2Farchive%2F2000%2F02%2F02%2Fnmir02.html |archivedate=22 November 2002 |accessdate=13 January 2015 |df= }} Morgan was found by the [[Press Complaints Commission]] to have breached the Code of Conduct on financial journalism, but kept his job. The "City Slickers" columnists, [[Anil Bhoyrul]] and [[James Hipwell]], were both found to have committed further breaches of the Code and were sacked before the inquiry concluded.{{cite news |last=Moyes |first=Jojo |author-link=Jojo Moyes |date=10 May 2000 |title=Columnist rewrites his 'Mirror' tips story over share tips |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/columnist-rewrites-his-mirror-tips-story-over-share-tips-279320.html |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=13 January 2015}} Further enquiry by the [[Department of Trade and Industry (United Kingdom)|Department of Trade and Industry]] in 2004 cleared Morgan of any charges.{{Cite news |title=Morgan cleared after shares probe |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/3792225.stm |publisher=BBC News |date=10 June 2004}} On 7 December 2005, Bhoyrul and Hipwell were convicted of conspiracy to breach the Financial Services Act. During the trial it emerged that Morgan had bought £67,000 worth of Viglen shares, emptying his bank account and investing under his (first) wife's name, too.{{cite news |last=Tryhorn |first=Chris |date=23 November 2005 |title=Mirror editor 'bought £67,000 of shares before they were tipped' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2005/nov/23/business.pressandpublishing |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=22 May 2010}} The ''Mirror'' attempted to move mid-market in 2002, eschewing the more trivial stories of show-business and gossip, but sales declined.{{cite news|last=Barber|first=Lynn|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2005/nov/20/newspaperformats.mirror|title='I should have been fired years ago, to be honest'|work=The Observer|date=20 November 2005|accessdate=16 July 2018}} In the wake of the [[Abu Ghraib torture and prisoner abuse|Abu Ghraib torture scandal]], Morgan was fired as Editor of the ''Daily Mirror'' "with immediate effect" on 14 May 2004, after refusing to apologise to [[Sly Bailey]], then head of [[Trinity Mirror]], for authorising the newspaper's publication of photographs which had been shown to be false.Chris Tryhorn and the photographs were shown to be crude fakes, under the headline "SORRY..WE WERE HOAXED", the ''Mirror'' responded that it had fallen victim to a "calculated and malicious hoax" and apologised for the accessdate = 2012-12-27 }}{{Cite news | url = http://www.cnn.com/2004/WORLD/meast/05/14/iraq.abuse.uk/ | title = Fake abuse photos: Editor quits | publisher = CNN | date = 15 May 2004 | archiveurl = 2018|work=POLITICO|date=18 January 2013}} ===Post-''Mirror'' press career (2005–present)=== In partnership with [[Matthew Freud]], he gained ownership in May 2005, of ''[[Press Gazette]]'', a media ''[[First News (newspaper)|First News]]'' was launched by Morgan on 4 May 2006. A weekly paper aimed at seven to 14-year-olds, he claimed at its launch that the paper was to be "Britain's first national newspaper for children"."Britain's first national newspaper for children to launch Friday", Associated Press, 4 May 2006Other newspapers aimed at young audiences have included ''The Boy's Newspaper'' (1880–1882), ''[[The Children's Newspaper]]'' (1919–1965), and ''Early Times'' (launched in the late 1980s) Morgan was editorial director at ''First News'', responsible for bringing in celebrity involvement. He referred to the role as "editorial overlord and frontman".{{Cite news |last=Burrell |first=Ian |title=Piers Morgan launches children's newspaper |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/piers-morgan-launches-childrens-newspaper-476277.html |newspaper=The Independent |date=1 May 2006 |accessdate=5 May 2006}} Morgan was filmed falling off a [[Segway PT|Segway]], breaking three ribs, in 2007. Bush]] fell off a Segway: "You'd have to be an idiot to fall off wouldn't you, Mr President".{{cite web|first=Andrew |last=Breitbart |url=http://www.breitbart.tv/reporter-who-called-bush-idiot-for-segway-fall-cracks-ribs-in-fall-from-contraption/ |title=Reporter Who Called Bush 'Idiot' for Segway Fall Cracks Ribs in Fall from Contraption |publisher=[[Breitbart TV]] |date=3 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100912212119/http://www.breitbart.tv/reporter-who-called-bush-idiot-for-segway-fall-cracks-ribs-in-fall-from-contraption/ |archivedate=12 September 2010 }}{{cite web | url = http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a73424/morgan-had-broken-ribs-in-talent-final.html | title = Morgan had broken ribs in 'Talent' final | publisher = Digital Spy | date = 23 August 2007 }}{{cite web | first = Charles C. 'Your TV shows are BRILLIANT!. he exclaimed. ... I've always loved Jimmy Savile."{{cite news|title=Piers Morgan: did he meet Jimmy Savile or didn't he?|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/londoners-diary/piers-morgan-did-he-meet-jimmy-savile-or-didnt-he-8222958.html|work=London Evening Standard|date=23 October 2012|accessdate=27 February 2017}} He became the editor-at-large of the ''[[Mail Online]]'' website's US operation in September 2014 and Morgan writes several columns a week.{{cite web|last=Deans|first=Jason|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/sep/30/piers-morgan-joins-mail-online|title=Piers Morgan joins Mail Online as US editor-at-large|work=The Guardian|date=30 September 2014|accessdate=24 January 2015}} He also writes a weekly diary for the ''[[Mail on Sunday]]'' ''Event'' magazine, having also written one for its predecessor ''Live''. ==Television career== Morgan's career expanded into television presenting before he left the ''Daily Mirror''. He presented a three-part television documentary series for the [[BBC]] titled ''The Importance of Being Famous'' (2003), about fame and the manner in which celebrities are covered by modern media. At the annual [[Pride of Britain Awards]] broadcast on [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]], Morgan chaired a panel of prominent people who had chosen the recipients of the awards from 1999 to 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.prideofbritain.com/contentPages/judges/default.aspx |title=Judges |author=The Pride of Britain Awards |publisher=Trinity Mirror Group |accessdate=26 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140217203455/http://www.prideofbritain.com/contentPages/judges/default.aspx |archivedate=17 February 2014 |df= }} He co-hosted a current affairs interview show on [[Channel 4]] with [[Amanda Platell]], ''Morgan and Platell''. Morgan and Platell were put together because of their opposing political viewpoints; Platell interrogated guests from the [[right wing]], Morgan from the [[left wing]].{{cite web | url= http://www.newstatesman.com/200411080018 | title= Amanda Platell notes Piers Morgan's two left feet|newspaper=New Statesman |date=8 November 2004}} The show was dropped after three series reputedly because of poor viewing figures, although the chairman of Channel 4 [[Luke Johnson (Businessman)|Luke Johnson]] was reported not to like the programme.[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2005/may/12/channel4.politicsandthemedia "Morgan and Platell to return on Channel 4"], ''MediaGuardian'', 12 May 2005 Throughout 2006, Morgan appeared as a judge on the television show ''[[America's Got Talent]]'' alongside [[Brandy Norwood]] and [[David Hasselhoff]] on [[NBC]]. Morgan was chosen by Simon Cowell as a replacement for himself because of the conditions of his ''[[American Idol]]'' contract. Morgan appeared as a celebrity contestant on ''[[Comic Relief Does The Apprentice]]'' in 2007, to raise money for the BBC charity telethon [[Comic Relief (charity)|Comic Relief]]. After his team lost, Morgan was selected by [[Alan Sugar|Sir Alan Sugar]] as the contestant to be fired.{{Cite news|url=http://tvnews.virginmedia.com/news/?news_id=7543|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080618102236/http://tvnews.virginmedia.com/news/?news_id=7543|archivedate=18 June 2008|title='Red Nose apprentice' Morgan fired|author=PA Entertainment|date= 16 March 2007|work=TV News|publisher=Virgin Media|accessdate=8 June 2008}} Also in 2007, Morgan appeared as a judge for the second season of ''America's Got Talent'' and also appeared as a judge on ''[[Britain's Got Talent]]'' on [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]], alongside [[Amanda Holden]] and Simon Cowell. He also presented ''You Can't Fire Me, I'm Famous'' on [[BBC One]]. He fronted a three-part documentary about [[Sandbanks]] for [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] entitled ''Piers Morgan on Sandbanks'' in January 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/Sandbanks/default.html|title=Sandbanks: Piers Morgan meets Dorset's mega-rich|date=10 January 2008|publisher=ITV|accessdate=8 June 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080621170129/http://www.itv.com/Sandbanks/default.html|archivedate=21 June 2008|df=dmy-all}} Morgan signed a two-year "[[golden handcuffs]]" deal with ITV in May 2008, reportedly worth £2 million per year. As part of the deal, he would continue as a judge on ''Britain's Got Talent'' for at least two more series and front a new [[Talk/Chat show|chat show]]. He also made some interview specials, plus three more documentaries from various countries. Morgan's golden handcuffs deal was the first signing by ITV's new director of television, [[Peter Fincham]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/may/29/itv.television|title=Piers Morgan: Britain's Got Talent judge signs two-year deal with ITV|last=Conlan|first=Tara|date= 29 May 2008|newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=8 June 2008}} On 8 September 2008, Morgan featured in ''[[The Dark Side of Fame with Piers Morgan]]'', produced by [[BBC Scotland]]. 2018|accessdate=15 July 2018}} From 2016–2017, Morgan interviewed female murderers on the TV series ''Killer Women with Piers Morgan''.{{Citation|title=Killer Women with Piers Morgan|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6172806/|others=Piers Morgan, Amanda Lewis, Sheila Davalloo|accessdate=2017-12-12}}{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2017/11/17/piers-morgan-calls-out-self-delusion-of-love-triangle-killer/|title=Piers Morgan calls out ‘self-delusion’ of love-triangle killer|date=2017-11-18|work=New York Post|access-date=2017-12-12|language=en-US}} He also presented ''Serial Killer with Piers Morgan'', as part of the 2017 Crime & Punishment season on ITV. In October 2018, Morgan appeared as a cameo on [[Hollyoaks]].{{cite news|url=https://www.radiotimes.com/news/2018-10-18/hollyoaks-storm-week-to-feature-piers-morgan-and-carol-kirkwood-cameos/|title=Hollyoaks storm week to feature Piers Morgan and Carol Kirkwood cameos|publisher=Radio Times|date=18 October 2018|accessdate=25 October 2018}} ===Donald Trump=== Morgan was the winner of the U.S. celebrity version of ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. season 7)|The Apprentice]]'', in 2008. He was eventually the overall winner, being named Celebrity Apprentice by host [[Donald Trump]] on 27 March, ahead of fellow finalist, American country music star [[Trace Adkins]],Johnson, Caitlin (28 March 2008). [https://www.today.com/popculture/relative-unknown-wins-celebrity-apprentice-wbna23838097 "Relative unknown wins ‘Celebrity Apprentice’"]. [[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]''. [[NBC]].[http://www.foxnews.com/story/2008/03/28/piers-morgan-beats-trace-adkins-on-celebrity-apprentice-finale.html "Piers Morgan Beats Trace Adkins on 'Celebrity Apprentice' Finale"]. [[Associated Press]]/[[Fox News]]. 28 March 2008. and having raised substantially more cash than all the other contestants combined.Rocchio, Christopher (28 March 2008). [http://www.realitytvworld.com/news/piers-morgan-defeats-trace-adkins-wins-the-celebrity-apprentice-6804.php "Piers Morgan defeats Trace Adkins, wins 'The Celebrity Apprentice'"]. Reality TV World. Morgan was called "ruthless, arrogant, evil and obnoxious" by Trump in the final.{{cite news|last=Morgan|first=Piers|url=http://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/article/gq-entertainment-donald-trump-interview-piers-morgan|title=Donald Trump on sex, money and politics|work=GQ|orig-year=December 2008|date=7 August 2015|accessdate=16 July 2018}} Morgan predicted Trump's election as [[President of the United States]] and has described himself as a close personal friend of Trump.{{cite news|last1=Morgan|first1=Piers|title=It’s weird when your friend becomes leader of the free world|url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/2016/12/its-weird-when-your-friend-becomes-leader-of-the-free-world/|work=The Spectator|date=10 December 2016}} Morgan interviewed Donald Trump on ''Good Morning Britain'' in March 2016.{{cite news|last=Demianyk|first=Graeme|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/donald-trump-piers-morgan-good-morning-britain_uk_56f230f1e4b08af01be9c210|title=Donald Trump Tells Piers Morgan That Muslims Are ‘Absolutely Not’ Reporting Terrorists|work=The Huffington Post|date=23 March 2016|accessdate=21 January 2017}} Morgan appeared on ITV's ''[[Loose Women]]'' panel show in late January 2017, and was challenged to repudiate Donald Trump. He refused to do so, despite stating that he disagreed with him on many issues relating to gun control, climate change, abortion and the [[Executive Order 13769|'Muslim travel ban']], saying that he found the principle of the ban understandable, but disagreed with "the way [Trump] has gone about it".{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2017/jan/30/piers-morgan-defends-friendship-with-donald-trump|title=Piers Morgan defends friendship with Donald Trump|work=The Guardian|date=31 January 2017|accessdate=1 February 2017}} Nearly a fortnight later, on the American talk show ''[[Real Time with Bill Maher]]'', Morgan said "There is no Muslim ban", as "85% of the world's Muslims are allowed in the country". Another participant in the discussion, Australian comedian [[Jim Jefferies (comedian)|Jim Jefferies]], immediately told him to "fuck off", adding in part "[[Hitler]] didn't kill the Jews on the first day, he worked up to it".{{cite news|last=Stolworthy|first=Jacob|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/jim-jefferies-piers-morgan-defence-of-donald-trump-muslim-ban-real-time-with-bill-maher-a7574746.html|title=Piers Morgan slammed by Jim Jefferies after defending Donald Trump on talk show ''Real Time with Bill Maher''|work=The Independent|date=11 February 2017|accessdate=11 February 2017}} After the novelist [[J. K. Rowling]] tweeted "Yes, watching Piers Morgan being told to fuck off on live TV is *exactly* as satisfying as I'd always imagined", the two began an exchange of words on the social media site.{{cite news|last=Horton|first=Helena|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/tv/2017/02/11/never-read-harry-potter-jk-rowling-piers-morgan-twitter-row/|title='This is why I've never read Harry Potter': JK Rowling and Piers Morgan in Twitter row|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=11 February 2017|accessdate=11 February 2017}}{{cite news|last=Thorpe|first=Vanessa|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2017/feb/11/jk-rowling-piers-morgan-trump-twitter-spat|title=Fantastic beefs and where to find them: JK Rowling at war with Piers Morgan|work=The Observer|date=11 February 2017|accessdate=12 February 2017}} Morgan criticised Trump after Trump retweeted [[Jayda Fransen]], deputy leader of the small right-wing party [[Britain First]] in late November 2017. He tweeted to Trump: "What the hell are you doing retweeting a bunch of unverified videos by Britain First, a bunch of disgustingly racist far-right extremists? Please STOP this madness & undo your retweets".{{cite news|last=Welsh|first=Daniel|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/donald-trump-retweets-britain-first-piers-morgan_uk_5a1ebbd5e4b0dc52b02ad20a|title=Piers Morgan Condemns Donald Trump Over Britain First Retweets|work=HuffPost|date=29 November 2017|accessdate=29 November 2017}} In January 2018, Morgan presented ''[[President Trump – The Piers Morgan Interview]]'' for ITV,{{cite news|first=Chloe |last=Farand|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/donald-trump-is-not-feminist-piers-morgan-interview-itv-a8181811.html |title=Donald Trump tells Piers Morgan: 'I wouldn't say I'm a feminist' |publisher=Independent Print Limited |work=The Independent |date=28 January 2018 |accessdate=28 January 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/uk-42850362/trump-i-would-have-taken-a-tougher-stand-in-getting-out |title=Trump: 'I would have taken a tougher stand in getting out' |work=BBC News|date=28 January 2018 |accessdate=28 January 2018}} which many thought of as "sycophantic" and a "love-in" for Trump.{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Paul|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/tv/2018-01-29/piers-morgan-too-soft-on-donald-trump-in-sycophantic-itv-love-in-interview/|title=88% of viewers say Piers Morgan was too soft on Donald Trump in 'sycophantic' ITV 'love-in' interview|work=Radio Times|date=29 January 2018|accessdate=3 February 2018}} 88% of respondents to a ''[[Radio Times]]'' Twitter poll viewed Morgan as being not "tough enough" on Trump. Morgan interviewed Trump again in July 2018 during his official visit to the UK, this time on [[Air Force One]] during an internal flight, in a TV special entitled ''Piers, The President And Air Force One''.{{cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/news/2018-07-15/donald-trump-piers-morgan-itv-good-morning-britain/|title=Donald Trump tells ITV the Queen is 'an incredible woman' – and US and UK will make 'a great trade deal'|work=ITV News|date=15 July 2018|accessdate=16 July 2018}} ==Feuds== ===Ian Hislop=== Morgan appeared as a guest on the satirical news quiz ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'' in an episode transmitted on 24 May 1996.[http://www.tv.com/have-i-got-news-for-you/felix-dexter-piers-morgan-clive-anderson/episode/143355/summary.html Have I Got News for You Episode Guide > Season 11, Episode 6] TV.com In it, show regular [[Ian Hislop]] accused Morgan of having him followed and having his house watched. The conflict escalated and at one point the host, [[Angus Deayton]], asked if they wished to go outside and have a fight. Later on, guest panellist [[Clive Anderson]] confronted Morgan commenting, "the last time I was rude to you, you sent photographers to my doorstep the next day", to which Piers Morgan retorted, "You won't see them this time." The audience responded loudly in favour of Hislop.''[[Have I Got News For You]]'' BBC2, Series 11 episode 6; Transmitted on 24 May 1996 "We're about to start exposing the moon-faced midget", Morgan was quoted as saying in 2002, to which Hislop responded, "all he's been offering for information about my private life is a £50 reward. My friends think that's not nearly enough." In 2007, Hislop chose Morgan as one of his pet hates on ''[[Room 101 (TV series)|Room 101]]''.''[[Room 101 (TV series)|Room 101]]'' BBC2, Series 11 episode 6; Transmitted on 9 February 2007[http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/tv/room_101/episodes/11/6/ Room 101 Episode 11.6 – Ian Hislop] British Comedy Guide In doing so, Hislop spoke of the history of animosity between himself and Morgan and revealed that after their exchange on ''Have I Got News For You'' (which was shown as a clip), Morgan's reporters were tasked with trying to get gossip on Hislop's private life (including phoning acquaintances of Hislop), and photographers were sent in case Hislop did anything untoward or embarrassing while in their presence. Neither the reporters nor the photographers succeeded. Hislop also revealed that Morgan had attempted to quell the feud in an article in ''[[The Mail on Sunday]]'', saying, "The war is over. I'm officially calling an end to hostilities, at least from my end. I'm sure it won't stop him carrying on his 'Piers Moron' stuff"{{cite book |last=Herbert |first=Emily |date=4 April 2011 |title=Piers Morgan: The Biography |url=http://www.johnblakepublishing.co.uk/e-store/Piers-Morgan-The-Biography.html |location=London |publisher=[[John Blake (journalist)#John Blake Publishing|John Blake Publishing Ltd]] |page= |isbn=1843583518 |accessdate=13 January 2015}} (''[[Private Eye]]'', the fortnightly satirical magazine which Hislop edits, regularly calls Morgan 'Piers Moron'){{cite news |author= |title=What a moron |newspaper=[[Private Eye]] |date=20 December 2014 }}{{cite news |last=Hattenstone |first=Simon |date=12 October 2013 |title=Piers Morgan: 'I want to be at the centre of the big stuff' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/oct/12/piers-morgan-shooting-straight |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=13 January 2015}}{{cite news |last=Ellison |first=Sarah |author-link=Sarah Ellison |date=November 2012 |title=Blood, Sweat, and Piers |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2012/11/piers-morgan-criticized-hated-than-ignored |newspaper=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] |accessdate=13 January 2015}} Hislop, who was working on a [[World War I]] documentary at the time, responded by asking "Is that an armistice or an unconditional surrender?" Although [[Paul Merton]] – host of ''Room 101'' at the time and regular team captain alongside Hislop at ''Have I Got News For You'' – agreed to put Morgan into ''Room 101'', he then comically rejected Morgan as being "too toxic" for ''Room 101''.[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/feb/10/broadcasting.tvandradio1 "Room 101, BBC1"], The Guardian, 10 February 2007{{cite news |last=Anthony |first=Andrew |author-link=Andrew Anthony |date=20 April 2010 |title=Piers Morgan: The man with stars in his eyes |url=https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2010/jun/20/profile-piers-morgan |newspaper=The Observer |accessdate=12 May 2014}} ===Others=== In October 2003, journalist and television personality [[Jeremy Clarkson]] reportedly emptied a glass of [[water]] over Morgan during the last flight of [[Concorde]] for some photographs published in the ''Mirror''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2004/mar/17/mediamonkey.pressandpublishing|author=Media Monkey|title=Clarkson and Morgan in tabloid tussle|newspaper=The Guardian|date=17 March 2004|accessdate=8 June 2008}} In March 2004, at the [[British Press Awards]], Clarkson punched Morgan three times during another argument. Morgan reported on a rapprochement with Clarkson in the epilogue of his book, ''Don't You Know Who I Am?'' On 4 February 2014, transgender advocate [[Janet Mock]] appeared as a guest on ''Piers Morgan Live'' to discuss her memoir, ''Redefining Realness''. After the interview aired, Mock sent a series of tweets criticising Morgan for describing Mock as being "formerly a man". Morgan responded that he had "never been treated in such a disgraceful manner" by a guest. On 5 February, Mock appeared as a guest again to debate the dispute.{{cite news|last=Hedgecock |first=Sarah |url=http://gawker.com/piers-morgan-demands-apology-from-disgraceful-trans-w-1516913568 |title=Piers Morgan Demands Apology from "Disgraceful" Trans Woman Guest |accessdate=6 February 2014 |newspaper=Gawker |date=5 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140206203218/http://gawker.com/piers-morgan-demands-apology-from-disgraceful-trans-w-1516913568 |archivedate= 6 February 2014 |df= }} Morgan strongly objected to the [[2017 Women's March|Women's March on Washington]] on 21 January 2017, the day after [[Inauguration of Donald Trump|Trump's inauguration]], describing protesters as "rabid feminists" and the multiple protests as being "vacuous".{{cite news|last1=Oppenheim|first1=Maya|title=Piers Morgan just accused Ewan McGregor of being 'paedophile-loving hypocrite'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/piers-morgan-ewan-mcgregor-accuse-paedophile-loving-hypocrite-good-morning-britain-no-show-t2-a7543911.html|accessdate=27 February 2017|work=The Independent|date=24 January 2017}} The actor [[Ewan McGregor]] disagreed with Morgan's statements on the women's march and pulled out of appearing on ''Good Morning Britain'' the following Tuesday after discovered Morgan would be interviewing him, along with Reid.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-38729770|title=Ewan McGregor and Piers Morgan row over Good Morning Britain appearance|publisher=BBC News|date=24 January 2017|accessdate=24 January 2017}} Morgan accused McGregor of being a "paedophile-loving hypocrite" for his past support of [[Roman Polanski]].{{cite news|last=Aitkenhead|first=Decca|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2017/jan/28/piers-morgan-im-just-putting-opinions-out-there-its-my-job|title=Piers Morgan: 'I’m just putting opinions out there. It’s my job'|work=The Guardian|date=28 January 2018|accessdate=16 July 2018}} ===Banned guests=== On 28 March 2012, MTV referred to the bad relations between Piers Morgan and [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], reporting that "Morgan has apparently felt slighted over the years by Madonna ... he claims he was lied to by the singer's publicist"."Madonna Banned..." by Gil Kaufman, ''MTV.com'', 28 March 2012; [http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1681945/madonna-banned-piers-morgan.jhtml retrieved 30 September 2012] In September 2012, it was reported that Morgan had also banned actor [[Kelsey Grammer]]. Morgan himself claimed, "Kelsey Grammer saw a photo of [[Camille Grammer|his ex-wife Camille]] in the open of our show and legged it.""Kelsey Grammer Walks Out on Piers Morgan", ''ABCNews'', 20 September 2012; [http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/entertainment/2012/09/kelsey-grammer-walks-out-on-piers-morgan retrieved 30 September 2012] ''[[TVGuide]]'' reported, "All plans were still a go for the segment until Grammer actually got in the hot seat and saw the footage the producers had planned to peg to the segment, including a picture of his ex-wife"."Kelsey Grammer storms off set" by Emily Gagne, ''TVGuide.ca'', 20 September 2012; [http://tvguide.ca/TVNews/Articles/120920_grammer_leaves_piers_EG.htm retrieved 30 September 2012]. On 26 September 2012, Fox 11 Los Angeles reported that "many say [it] was an ambush by Piers".Official Facebook page: ''FOX 11 Flash'', 26 September 2012; [https://www.facebook.com/FOX11Flash retrieved 30 September 2012] ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' reported that "before the interview was scheduled, it was made clear that Grammer would answer all questions, including those about [his ex-wife]. His sole request was not to show any images of her.""Kelsey Grammer, Piers Morgan: Actor Barred...", ''Huffington Post'', 27 September 2012; [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/27/kelsey-grammer-piers-morgan-cnn_n_1919662.html retrieved 30 September 2012] Morgan also banned actor [[Hugh Grant]] from his shows on CNN and ITV in May 2011 after Grant denigrated the tabloid press. On Twitter he responded: "Hugh Grant is now banned, in perpetuity, from @PiersTonight and Life Stories and anything else I ever do. Tedious little man."{{cite news|url=https://www.pressgazette.co.uk/piers-morgan-bans-tedious-little-man-hugh-grant-from-cnn-show/|title=Piers Morgan bans 'tedious little man' Hugh Grant from CNN show|work=Press Gazette|date=18 May 2011|accessdate=16 July 2018}} ==Phone hacking allegations== During Morgan's tenure as editor, the ''Daily Mirror'' was advised by Steven Nott that voicemail interception was possible by means of a standard PIN code. Despite staff initially expressing enthusiasm for the story it did not appear in the paper, although it did subsequently feature in a ''[[South Wales Argus]]'' article and on [[BBC Radio 5 Live]] in October 1999. On 18 July 2011 Nott was visited by officers of [[Operation Weeting]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/press/this-scandal-is-all-my-fault-says-salesman-2332669.html|first=Matt|last=Blake|title=This scandal is all my fault, says salesman|newspaper=The Independent|date=6 August 2011|accessdate=6 August 2011}} He came under criticism for his "boasting" about phone hacking from [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Member of Parliament|MP]] [[Louise Mensch]], who has since apologised for these accusations.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-14346050 |publisher=BBC News |title=MP Mensch apologises to Piers Morgan for hacking slur |date=29 July 2011}} In July 2011, in a sequence of articles, political blogger [[Paul Staines]] alleged that while editor of the ''Daily Mirror'' in 2002 Morgan published a story concerning the affair of [[Sven-Goran Eriksson]] and [[Ulrika Jonsson]] while knowing it to have been obtained by [[phone hacking]].{{cite news |last=Young |first=Toby |author-link=Toby Young |date=29 July 2011 |title=The net closes around Piers Morgan |url=http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/tobyyoung/100098912/the-net-closes-around-piers-morgan/ |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=13 January 2015}} On 20 December 2011, Morgan was a witness by satellite link from the United States at the [[Leveson Inquiry]].[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-16259941 "Piers Morgan tells Leveson: Daily Mirror did not hack phones"], BBC News, 20 December 2011 While he said he had no reason to believe that phone hacking had occurred at the ''Mirror'' while he was in charge there, he admitted to hearing a recording of an answerphone message left by [[Paul McCartney]] for [[Heather Mills]], but refused to "discuss where that tape was played or who made [it] – it would compromise a source." Appearing as a witness at the same Inquiry on 9 February 2012, Mills was asked under oath if she had ever made a recording of Paul McCartney's phone call or had played it to Piers Morgan; she replied: "Never".{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/leveson-inquiry/9071901/Leveson-Inquiry-Heather-Mills-vows-she-did-not-play-Paul-McCartney-messages-to-Piers-Morgan.html|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|title=Leveson Inquiry: Heather Mills vows she did not play Paul McCartney messages to Piers Morgan|date=9 February 2012}}{{cite web|author=Michael Holden|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/02/09/us-britain-hacking-morgan-idUSTRE8181CL20120209|publisher=[[Reuters]]|title=Beatle's ex-wife says Piers Morgan heard hacked call|date=9 February 2012}} She said that she had never authorised Morgan, or anybody, to access or listen to her voicemails. Mills told the inquiry that Morgan, "a man that has written nothing but awful things about me for years", would have relished telling the inquiry if she had played a personal voicemail message to him. On 23 May 2012, ''[[Newsnight]]'' presenter [[Jeremy Paxman]] was a witness at the Leveson Inquiry. He recalled a lunch with the ''Mirror'' editor in September 2002 at which Morgan outlined the means of hacking into a mobile phone.Dan Sabbagh and Lisa O'Carroll [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/may/23/leveson-piers-morgan-paxman "Piers Morgan told me how to hack a phone, says Jeremy Paxman"], ''The Guardian'', 23 May 2012. On 28 November 2012, the [[Channel 4]] documentary ''Taking on the Tabloids'', fronted by actor and phone hacking victim [[Hugh Grant]], showed footage from a 2003 interview with Morgan by the singer and phone hacking victim [[Charlotte Church]], during which he explained to her how to avoid answerphone messages being listened to by journalists. He said: "You can access ... voicemails by typing in a number. Now, are you really telling me that journalists aren’t going to do that?"{{cite web|author=Matilda Battersby|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/video-from-2003-shows-piers-morgan-talking-about-phone-hacking-8364468.html|title=Video from 2003 shows Piers Morgan talking about phone hacking|newspaper=The Independent|date=28 November 2012|accessdate=24 December 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tntmagazine.com/news/uk/video-new-clip-surfaces-showing-piers-morgan-talking-to-charlotte-church-about-phone-hacking|title=Video: New clip surfaces showing Piers Morgan talking to Charlotte Church about phone hacking|newspaper=[[TNT (magazine)|TNT]]|date=28 November 2012|accessdate=24 December 2012}} On 29 November 2012, the official findings of the [[Leveson Inquiry]] were released, in which [[Lord Justice Leveson]] said that Morgan's testimony under oath on phone hacking was "utterly unpersuasive". He stated: "[The] evidence does not establish that [Morgan] authorised the hacking of voicemails or that journalists employed by TMG [Trinity Mirror Group] were indulging in this practice ... What it does, however, clearly prove is that he was aware that it was taking place in the press as a whole and that he was sufficiently unembarrassed by what was criminal behaviour that he was prepared to joke about it."{{cite news |url=http://www.itv.com/news/2012-11-28/key-moments-from-the-leveson-inquiry |title=Key moments from the Leveson Inquiry |publisher=ITV News |date=28 November 2012 |accessdate=24 December 2012}} {{wikinews|Piers Morgan interviewed by police investigating phone hacking}} On 6 December 2013, Morgan was interviewed, under caution, by police officers from Operation Weeting investigating phone hacking allegations at ''[[Mirror Group Newspapers]]'' during his tenure as editor.Martin Evans [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/10638562/Piers-Morgan-questioned-by-police-over-phone-hacking.html "Piers Morgan questioned by police over phone-hacking"], telegraph,.co.uk, 14 February 2014 On 24 September 2014, the [[Trinity Mirror|Trinity Mirror publishing group]] admitted for the first time that some of its journalists had been involved in phone hacking and agreed to pay compensation to four people who sued for the alleged hacking of voicemails.Gallivan, Rory and Zekaria, Simon (September 2014) [https://online.wsj.com/articles/trinity-mirror-admits-liability-over-phone-hacking-1411547673 “Trinity Mirror Admits Liability Over Phone Hacking”], ''Wall Street Journal'', 24 September 2014. Retrieved 29 September 2014Sweney, Mark (September 2014). [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/sep/28/trinity-mirror-phone-hacking-claims-compensation “Trinity Mirror faces up to the financial fallout as phone-hacking claims mount”], ''The Guardian'', 28 September 2014. Retrieved 29 September 2014. Six other phone-hacking claims had already been settled. The BBC reported that it had seen legal papers showing that although the alleged hacking could have taken place as early as 1998, the bulk of the alleged wrongdoing took place in the early 2000s when Morgan was the ''Daily Mirror'' editor.BBC News online [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-29339756 “Phone-hacking: Trinity Mirror admits liability”], BBC News online, 24 September 2014 (Retrieved 29 September 2014) The admissions by Trinity Mirror came whilst the London Metropolitan Police investigation into the phone hacking allegations was ongoing. Morgan has always denied any involvement in the practice. ==Personal life== Morgan married Marion Shalloe, a hospital ward sister, in 1991. The couple had three sons, and divorced in 2008.{{cite news|last=Burrell|first=Ian|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/piers-morgan-hack-of-the-day-1898171.html|title=Piers Morgan: Hack of the day|work=The Independent|date=13 February 2010|accessdate=16 July 2018}} In June 2010, he married his second wife, journalist [[Celia Walden]], daughter of the former [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Member of Parliament|MP]] [[George Walden]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/7853270/Piers-Morgan-marries-the-Telegraphs-Celia-Walden.html|title=Piers Morgan marries Celia Walden|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=25 June 2010|accessdate=16 July 2018}} Morgan announced in mid 2011 that the couple were expecting a child,http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20500210,00.html and on 25 November 2011, Walden gave birth to Elise Morgan, her first child and Morgan's fourth.http://www.celebritybabyscoop.com/2012/11/27/first-glimpse-of-piers-morgans-daughter-elise Morgan is a fan of [[Premier League]] football club [[Arsenal F.C.]]{{cite news|title=‘Wenger fails again’ – Piers Morgan scathing of Arsenal boss after David Ospina howler|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/champions-league/wenger-fails-again-piers-morgan-scathing-of-arsenal-boss-after-david-ospina-howler-31569375.html|publisher=Irish Independent|date=14 October 2015}} He was a consistent critic of former Arsenal manager [[Arsène Wenger]] and called for his sacking on many occasions. Speaking in defence of Wenger in 2015, former Arsenal goalkeeper [[Bob Wilson (footballer, born 1941)|Bob Wilson]] labelled Morgan an "incredibly pompous individual".{{cite news|last=Menezes|first=Jack de|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/piers-morgan-hurt-after-arsenal-legend-bob-wilson-questions-his-support-for-the-gunners-and-labels-10073107.html|title=Piers Morgan 'hurt' after Arsenal legend Bob Wilson questions his support for the Gunners and labels him a 'pompous individual'|work=The Independent|date=26 February 2015|accessdate=16 July 2018}} When Arsenal midfielder [[Aaron Ramsey]] met Morgan on 26 April 2015, Ramsey refused to shake his hand due to the criticism he received from Morgan during the 2012–13 season. Morgan has responded by calling Ramsey 'whatshisname'.[https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/aaron-ramsey-well-within-his-rights-to-refuse-handshake-with-arsenal-fan-piers-morgan-says-ian-10209316.html "Aaron Ramsey 'well within his rights' to refuse handshake with Arsenal fan Piers Morgan, says Ian Wright"].
