Trump responds|date=January 31, 2016|publisher=Fox News|language=en-US|accessdate=June 14, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/donald-trump-marriage-equality_us_56af63c8e4b00b033aafb496 |title=Trump: I Would 'Strongly Consider' Appointing Judges To Overturn Same-Sex Marriage |publisher=Huffington Post |date=February 1, 2016}}</ref> When asked if gay couples should be able access the same [[Rights and responsibilities of marriages in the United States|benefits as married couples]], Trump said that his "attitude on it has not been fully formed."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.desmoinesregister.com/dmr/index.php/2011/03/03/register-exclusive-trump-says-he-would-play-in-iowa-aides-to-visit-monday|title=Trump says he would play in Iowa, aides to visit Monday|website=The Des Moines Register|accessdate=May 26, 2016}}</ref> ''[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]'', an American [[LGBT]]-interest magazine, characterized Trump's Supreme Court picks as "LGBT-unfriendly," noting that "not all have ruled in LGBT rights cases, but those who have are largely unsympathetic, and some have the backing of anti-LGBT activists."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.advocate.com/election/2016/5/18/trumps-lgbt-unfriendly-supreme-court-picks|title=Trump's LGBT-Unfriendly Supreme Court Picks|date=May 18, 2016|website=www.advocate.com|accessdate=June 14, 2016}}</ref>
In November 2016, shortly after the presidential election, Trump told [[Lesley Stahl]] on ''[[60 Minutes]]'' that his personal view on same-sex marriage was "irrelevant" and that he was "fine with" same-sex marriage, stating that the issue was "settled" in the ''Obergefell'' decision.<ref name="EconomistSettled"/><ref>Eli Stokols, [http://www.politico.com/story/2016/11/donald-trump-same-sex-marriage-231310 Trump says he's 'fine' with legalization of same-sex marriage], ''Politico'' (November 13, 2016).</ref>
====Other statements==== Trump is the first Republican presidential nominee to mention the LGBT community at a [[Republican National Convention]] acceptance speech,<ref>Meridith McGraw, [http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-gop-nominee-mention-lgbtq-citizens-acceptance-speech/story?id=40791340 Trump Is First GOP Nominee to Mention LGBTQ Citizens in Acceptance Speech], ABC News (July 21, 2016).</ref> saying in his acceptance speech at the [[2016 Republican National Convention]]: "As your president, I will do everything in my power to protect our LGBTQ citizens from the violence and oppression of a hateful foreign ideology"—a reference to [[fundamentalist Islam]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/card/trump-i-will-protect-our-lgbtq-citizens-n614621|title= Trump: "I Will Protect Our LGBTQ Citizens'|publisher=NBC News|date=July 22, 2016}}</ref>
===Presidency=== As a political candidate, Trump largely avoided issues related to lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender rights, even while many in his family — including daughter Ivanka Trump — have been vocal supporters of LGBT people. But since taking office, the Trump administration has rolled back a number of protections, including those for transgender schoolchildren.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2017/07/26/trump-announces-ban-on-transgender-people-in-u-s-military/|title=Trump announces ban on transgender people in U.S. military|last=|first=|last2=|date=|website=Washington Post|access-date=2017-07-26|last3=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Danilova|first1=Maria|last2=Gurman|first2=Sadie|title=Trump administration revokes transgender bathroom guidance|website=[[The Republican (Springfield, Massachusetts)|MassLive.com]]|publisher=[[Advance Publications]]|url=https://www.masslive.com/politics/index.ssf/2017/02/trump_administration_revokes_t.html|date=February 22, 2017|accessdate=October 17, 2018}}</ref>
On January 30, 2017, Donald Trump and the White House stated that they would keep in place a 2014 executive order from the Obama administration which created federal workplace protections for LGBT people, with the White House released a statement saying that the President was "respectful and supportive of LGBTQ rights" and noted that he was the first Republican nominee to raise the issue in his acceptance speech as the [[2016 Republican National Convention]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Peters|first1=Jeremy W.|title=Obama's Protections for L.G.B.T. Workers Will Remain Under Trump|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/30/us/politics/obama-trump-protections-lgbt-workers.html|accessdate=February 2, 2017|work=The New York Times|date=January 30, 2017}}</ref> However, in March 2017, the Trump administration rolled back key components of the Obama administration's workplace protections for LGBT people.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/lgbtq-advocates-say-trump-s-news-executive-order-makes-them-n740301|title=LGBTQ advocates say Trump's new executive order removes protections against job discrimination|work=NBC News|access-date=2017-07-30|language=en}}</ref> The Trump administration rescinded requirements that federal contractors prove that they are complying with the LGBT workplace protections, which makes it difficult to tell if a contractor had refrained from discriminatory practices against LGBT individuals.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.advocate.com/politics/2017/3/29/trump-covertly-dismantles-obama-era-lgbt-protections|title=Trump Covertly Dismantles Obama-Era LGBT Protections|date=2017-03-29|access-date=2017-07-30|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":2" /> LGBT advocates have argued that this is a signal that the Trump administration will not enforce workplace violations against LGBT people.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/30/lgbt-rights-under-trump|title='Death by a thousand cuts': LGBT rights fading under Trump, advocates say|last=Siddiqui|first=Sabrina|date=2017-03-30|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-30|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" />
In February 2017, Trump's Justice Department withdrew a motion that had previously been filed by the Justice Department, "seeking to allow transgender students in public schools to use the restroom with which they identify." The move, which occurred within two days of [[Jeff Sessions]] becoming U.S. Attorney General, was condemned by the [[Human Rights Campaign]], an LGBT rights advocacy group.<ref>Andrew V. Pestano, [http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2017/02/13/Trumps-DOJ-withdraws-Obama-effort-over-transgender-bathroom-case/8671487008563/ Trump's DOJ withdraws Obama effort over transgender bathroom case], [[United Press International|UPI]] (February 13, 2017).</ref>
Also in February, the Trump administration kept U.S. diplomat [[Randy W. Berry]] in his position as the State Department's Special Envoy for the Human Rights of LGBTI Persons, a post created in 2015 under the Obama administration. This move surprised pro-LGBT rights groups such as [[GLAAD]] and was a defeat for [[Christian right]] groups such as the [[Family Research Council]], which "implored Trump to launch a major purge of pro-LGBT diplomats inside Foggy Bottom."<ref>John Hudson, [https://foreignpolicy.com/2017/02/13/trump-keeps-obamas-top-gay-rights-envoy-at-state-department/ Trump Keeps Obama's Top Gay Rights Envoy at State Department], ''Foreign Policy'' (February 13, 2017).</ref> But the position was vacant less than six months later.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.archive.org/web/20170727032140/https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/biog/title/as/237773.htm|title=Envoy for the Human Rights of LGBTI Persons: Vacant (Archive)|publisher=U.S. State Department|date=July 27, 2017|accessdate=October 21, 2018}}</ref> Berry was reassigned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonblade.com/2017/11/30/randy-berry-no-longer-us-lgbti-envoy/|title=Randy Berry is no longer US LGBTI envoy|publisher=Washington Blade|date=November 30, 2017|accessdate=October 21, 2018}}</ref> The position remained vacant as of 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/biog/title/as/237773.htm|title=Special Envoy for the Human Rights of LGBTI Persons: Vacant|publisher=U.S. State Department|accessdate=October 21, 2018|quote=This position is currently vacant.}}</ref>
In March 2017, the Trump administration rolled back efforts to collect data on LGBT Americans.<ref name=":4" /> The Health and Human Services removed a question about sexual orientation in a survey of the elderly.<ref name=":4" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://apnews.com/8443749ce29947f3b57f5e86e6c038e9|title=Federal surveys trim LGBT questions, alarming advocates|work=AP News|access-date=2017-07-30|language=en-US}}</ref> The U.S. Census Bureau, which had planned to ask about sexual orientation and gender identity in the 2020 Census and the American Community Survey, scrapped those plans in March 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/29/521921287/u-s-census-to-leave-sexual-orientation-gender-identity-questions-off-new-surveys|title=U.S. Census To Leave Sexual Orientation, Gender Identity Questions Off New Surveys|work=NPR.org|access-date=2017-07-30|language=en}}</ref>
On July 26, 2017, Trump announced on [[Twitter]] that [[transgender]] people would not be allowed to serve in the military "in any capacity", saying that American forces could not afford the "tremendous medical costs and disruption" of transgender service members.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Davis|first1=Julie Hirschfeld|title=Trump Says Transgender People Will Not Be Allowed in the Military|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/26/us/politics/trump-transgender-military.html|accessdate=July 27, 2017|work=The New York Times|date=July 26, 2017}}</ref> However, a RAND study of 18 countries that allow transgender individuals to serve in the military found "little or no impact on unit cohesion, operational effectiveness, or readiness."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/identities/2017/7/26/16034040/trump-transgender-military-study|title=Trump: allowing transgender military service would hurt combat readiness. Actual research: nope.|work=Vox|access-date=2017-07-26}}</ref> Also, according to the ''Scientific American'', studies have shown that the medical costs for transgender service members would be "minimal".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/cost-of-medical-care-for-transgender-service-members-would-be-minimal-studies-show/|title=Cost of Medical Care for Transgender Service Members Would Be Minimal, Studies Show|last=Joseph, STAT|first=Andrew|work=Scientific American|access-date=2017-07-26|language=en}}</ref> [[The Pentagon|Pentagon]] officials expressed dismay that Trump's tweets could open them up to lawsuits and the chairman of the [[Joint Chiefs of Staff]] said that the policy on who is allowed to serve would not change until the [[White House]] sends the [[United States Department of Defense|Defense Department]] new rules and the secretary of defense issues new guidelines.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cooper|first1=Helene|title=Transgender People Can Still Serve for Now, U.S. Military Says|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/27/us/politics/transgender-military-trump-ban.html|accessdate=July 27, 2017|work=The New York Times|date=July 27, 2017}}</ref> On August 25 Trump signed a memo prohibiting transgender individuals from joining the armed services unless the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Homeland Security recommend otherwise. The departments of Defense and Homeland Security are directed to determine what to do about currently serving transgender individuals.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/08/25/546216624/trump-signs-memo-implementing-ban-on-transgender-people-in-the-military|title=Trump Signs Memo Implementing Ban On Transgender People Enlisting In The Military|last=Kane|first=Jim|date=August 25, 2017|work=NPR|accessdate=28 August 2017}}</ref>
Also on July 26, the Department of Justice argued in court that federal civil rights law does not ban employers from discriminating against employees based on sexual orientation. The Obama administration had decided that it did.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-lgbt-idUSKBN1AC2DZ|title=U.S. Justice Department says anti-bias law does not protect gay workers|date=July 28, 2017|work=Reuters|accessdate=2017-07-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/27/nyregion/justice-department-gays-workplace.html|title=Justice Department Says Rights Law Doesn't Protect Gays|last=Feuer|first=Alan|date=2017-07-27|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-07-30|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
The policy change faced legal challenges. Following a challenge in the [[United States District Court for the District of Columbia|U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia]], on October 30, 2017 Judge [[Colleen Kollar-Kotelly]] blocked enforcement of the ban, writing that as far as could be seen, ''"all of the reasons proffered by the president for excluding transgender individuals from the military in this case were not merely unsupported, but were actually contradicted by the studies, conclusions and judgment of the military itself"''.<ref>http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-trump-transgender-20171030-story.html</ref><ref>[https://ecf.dcd.uscourts.gov/cgi-bin/show_public_doc?2017cv1597-61 Doe v Trump, 30 October 2017, District Court for Columbia, memorandum opinion]</ref> In March 2018, Trump announced a new policy on transgender service members, namely a ban on those with a diagnosis of gender dysphoria, which would effectively be a ban on most transgender service members.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/white-house-announces-ban-on-most-transgender-service-members/|title=White House announces ban on most transgender service members|access-date=2018-03-24|language=en}}</ref> The new policy was challenged in the [[United States District Court for the Western District of Washington|U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington]]. On April 13, 2018 Judge [[Marsha J. Pechman]] blocked enforcement of the policy, ruling that the administration's updated policy essentially repeated the same issues as its predecessor order from 2017, and that transgender service members (and transgender individuals as a class) were a [[protected class]] entitled to [[strict scrutiny]] of adverse laws (or at worst, a [[quasi-suspect class]]), and ordered that matter continue to a full trial hearing on the legality of the proposed policy.<ref>https://edition.cnn.com/2017/10/30/politics/judge-blocks-trump-transgender-military-ban/index.html</ref><ref>http://lawprofessors.typepad.com/conlaw/2018/04/district-judge-holds-transgender-military-ban-subject-to-strict-scrutiny.html</ref><ref>[http://lawprofessors.typepad.com/files/karnoskivtrump.pdf District Court, West District Washington, Karnoski v Trump, 13 April 2018]</ref><ref>http://lawprofessors.typepad.com/conlaw/2017/12/another-district-judge-issues-preliminary-injunction-against-transgender-military-ban-.html</ref>
On November 23rd 2018, the Trump-appointed officials removed the [[Office of Personnel Management]] guidance intended to protect [[gender transition|transitioning]] employees against adverse actions.<ref>https://transequality.org/press/releases/trump-administration-erases-key-guidelines-for-transgender-federal-employees</ref>
==Pornography== Trump signed a pledge in July 2016 that he would work to combat both legal [[Pornography in the United States|pornography]] and illegal pornography, such as [[child pornography]].<ref name=":21">{{Cite web|author=Craig Hlavaty|url=http://www.chron.com/news/nation-world/article/Donald-Trump-says-he-will-crack-down-on-internet-8976017.php|title=Donald Trump says he will crack down on internet porn while in office|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|date=August 1, 2016}}</ref> In the pledge, put forth by the [[Anti-pornography|anti-pornography group]] [[Enough Is Enough (organization)|Enough Is Enough]], Trump promised to "give serious consideration to appointing a Presidential Commission to examine the harmful public health impact of Internet pornography on youth, families and the American culture and the prevention of the sexual exploitation of children in the digital age."<ref name=":21" />
==Privacy, encryption, and electronic surveillance== {{See also|Mass surveillance in the United States|FBI–Apple encryption dispute}} On [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) surveillance, Trump says that he "tends to err on the side of security" over privacy. Trump supports bringing back now-expired provisions of the [[Patriot Act]] to allow for the NSA to collect and store bulk telephone [[metadata]].<ref name="ByrnesNSA">Jesse Byrnes, [http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/presidential-races/261673-trump-sides-with-rubio-over-cruz-in-nsa-surveillance Trump sides with Rubio over Cruz in NSA surveillance debate], ''The Hill'' (December 1, 2015).</ref><ref name="BradnerNSADecember1">Eric Bradner, [http://www.cnn.com/2015/12/01/politics/donald-trump-nsa-surveillance/ Trump: 'Err on the side of security'], CNN (December 1, 2015).</ref> Trump said: "I assume that when I pick up my telephone, people are listening to my conversations anyway."<ref name="BradnerNSADecember1"/>
In February 2016, Trump urged his supporters to [[boycott]] [[Apple Inc.]] unless the company agrees to build a custom [[Backdoor (computing)|backdoor]] for the FBI to unlock the password-protected [[iPhone]] connected to one of the perpetrators of the [[2015 San Bernardino shooting]], a move that Apple argues would threaten the security and privacy of its users.<ref>Jeremy Diamond, [http://www.cnn.com/2016/02/19/politics/donald-trump-apple-boycott/index.html Trump calls for Apple boycott], CNN (February 19, 2016).</ref> Trump himself still uses his iPhone to send out tweets.<ref>Brian Fung, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/02/19/donald-trump-called-for-boycotting-apple-but-hes-still-tweeting-from-an-iphone/ Trump wants you to boycott Apple — but he's still tweeting from an iPhone], ''Washington Post'' (February 19, 2016).</ref>
==Race relations== {{See also|Racial views of Donald Trump}} Donald Trump is consistent in finding no fault on the part of law enforcement when it clashes with racial minorities and in dismissing contrary evidence. In April 2017, Trump was accused of being Islamophobic while presenting [[Executive Order 13769]], which blocked people from seven Muslim-majority countries from entering the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/executive-order-protecting-nation-foreign-terrorist-entry-united-states/}}</ref>
Trump has criticized the [[Black Lives Matter]] movement and accused former President Obama of "dividing America."<ref name="TrumpBLMDivisive">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/jul/13/donald-trump-strikes-muddled-note-on-divisive-black-lives-matter|title=Donald Trump strikes muddled note on 'divisive' Black Lives Matter|last=Siddiqui|first=Sabrina|date=July 13, 2016|website=The Guardian}}</ref> Speaking to [[Bill O'Reilly (political commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]] during his presidential campaign, Trump said that he may direct his [[United States Attorney General|Attorney General]] to look into the [[Black Lives Matter]] movement for criminal charges.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/presidential-races/288251-trump-calls-into-bill-oreilly-show-in-midst-of-convention|title=Trump calls into Bill O'Reilly show during convention|last=Master|first=Cyra|newspaper=The Hill|date=July 19, 2016|accessdate=July 19, 2016}}</ref> When asked if he believes there to be a [[racial segregation|racial divide]] in America, Trump answered, "Sadly, there would seem to be...and it's probably not been much worse at any time." When asked if he believes police treat African Americans differently than whites, Trump answered, "It could be."<ref name="TrumpOReilly">{{cite web|url=http://theweek.com/speedreads/635624/donald-trump-explains-plan-heal-americas-racial-divide-bill-oreilly|title=Donald Trump explains his plan to heal America's racial divide to Bill O'Reilly|date=July 13, 2016|magazine=The Week}}</ref> Trump describes the police [[Shooting of Alton Sterling|killings of Alton Sterling]] and [[Shooting of Philando Castile|Philando Castile]] as "tough to watch" and criticized the "terrible, disgusting performance" by police.<ref name="TrumpBLMDivisive"/> Trump said that he could relate to the systemic bias African Americans faced against whites, saying, "even against me the system is rigged when I ran ... for president." When asked if he could understand the experience of being African American, Trump replied, "I would like to say yes, but you really can't unless you are African American. You can't truly understand what's going on unless you are African American. I would like to say yes, however."<ref>{{cite web |last=Collins |first=Eliza |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2016/07/13/trump-african-americans/87027114/|title=Trump to blacks: System rigged against me, too |date=July 13, 2016 |work=USA TODAY |accessdate=July 16, 2016}}</ref>
On November 19, 2015, a week after the [[November 2015 Paris attacks]], when asked if he would implement a database system to track [[Muslims in the United States]], Trump said: "I would certainly implement that. Absolutely. There should be a lot of systems, beyond databases. We should have a lot of systems." On November 21, Trump clarified that he doesn't support any registry of Muslims in the US and said that his earlier supportive remarks for surveilling Muslims were due to efforts by news media to entrap him. He however said that he would order "surveillance of certain mosques" to combat "[[Islamic extremism]]",<ref name=":0">{{cite news|author=Maggie Haberman|title=Donald Trump Calls for Surveillance of 'Certain Mosques' and a Syrian Refugee Database |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/22/us/politics/donald-trump-syrian-muslims-surveillance.html|newspaper=The New York Times |date=November 22, 2015}}</ref><ref name="MSNBC_Nov11_2015">{{cite web |last1=Hillyard |first1=Vaughn |title=Trump's plan for a Muslim database draws comparison to Nazi Germany |url=http://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/trump-would-certainly-implement-muslim-database |publisher=MSNBC |accessdate=November 23, 2015}}</ref> alluding to the New York Police Department's use of informants in mosques after the [[September 11 attacks]]. Trump also spoke in favor of a database on Syrian refugees without clarifying how it would be different from the records already kept by federal agencies.<ref name=":0" /> Trump's support for a database of American Muslims "drew sharp rebukes from his Republican presidential rivals and disbelief from legal experts."<ref name="CarrollNov22">Lauren Carroll, [http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2015/nov/22/donald-trump/fact-checking-trumps-claim-thousands-new-jersey-ch/ Fact-checking Trump's claim that thousands in New Jersey cheered when World Trade Center tumbled], ''PolitiFact'' (November 22, 2015).</ref> Trump justified his proposals by repeatedly saying that he recalled "thousands and thousands of people ... cheering" in [[Jersey City, New Jersey]], when the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] towers fell.<ref name="MSNBC_Nov11_2015" /><ref>Jordyn Phelps, [http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/donald-trump-cheering-jersey-911/story?id=35355447 Donald Trump Again Says He Saw Cheering in New Jersey on 9/11], ABC News (November 22, 2015).</ref> [[PolitiFact]] noted that this statement was false and gave it a "Pants on Fire" rating. It reported that the rating was based on some debunked rumors and also that there were only eight people (suggested by unproven media reports) purported to be seen cheering, as opposed to Trump's claim of "thousands and thousands".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/article/2015/dec/02/new-information-doesnt-fix-donald-trumps-911-claim/|title=New information doesn't fix Donald Trump's 9/11 claim|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/more-questions-emerge-over-trumps-911-celebrations-claim/|title=More questions emerge over Trump's 9/11 celebrations claim|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="CarrollNov22" /><ref name="CarrollDec2">Lauren Carroll [http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/article/2015/dec/02/new-information-doesnt-fix-donald-trumps-911-claim/ New information doesn't fix Donald Trump's 9/11 claim], ''PolitiFact'' (December 2, 2015).</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Gonyea |first1=Don |title=Trump Reasserts Claim That 'Thousands' Of N.J. Muslims Cheered After Sept. 11 |url=https://www.npr.org/2015/11/24/457203786/trump-tells-ohio-crowd-he-will-be-tough-on-isis |publisher=NPR |date=November 24, 2015 |accessdate=November 27, 2015}}</ref> Jersey City Mayor [[Steve Fulop]] called Trump's claim "absurd" and said that Trump "has memory issues or willfully distorts the truth."<ref>Brent Johnson, [http://www.nj.com/politics/index.ssf/2015/11/trump_thousands_in_jersey_city_cheered_on_911.html Trump: 'Thousands' in Jersey City cheered on 9/11 (VIDEO)], [[NJ.com]] (November 22, 2015).</ref>
=== White supremacy === [[File:2017 Charlottesville ramming (car involved).jpg|thumb|alt=Silver gray late model compact car in an intersection dragging its front bumper area|Car that rammed protesters and killed a woman in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]], August 2017]] In June 2017, the Department of Homeland Security dropped a planned 400,000 dollar grant to "Life After Hate", a program which was intended to de-radicalize [[Neo-Nazism|Neo-Nazis]] and stop white extremism.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/06/23/playbook-dhs-extremism-life-after-hate-239889|title=DHS halts planned funding for anti-white extremism group|work=POLITICO|access-date=August 13, 2017}}</ref> The change came following a review of priorities, begun during the Obama administration, with regards to a 10 million dollar DHS umbrella grant program for "Countering Violent Extremism".
In August 2017, Trump condemned violence "on many sides" after a car plowed into counter-protesters during [[2017 Unite the Right rally|a gathering]] of hundreds of [[White nationalism|white nationalists]] in Charlottesville, Virginia the previous day, on August 12.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/08/13/republicans-and-democrats-speak-out-after-trump-faults-many-sides-at-white-nationalist-rally.html|title=Republicans and Democrats speak out after Trump faults 'many sides' at white nationalist rally|last=CNBC|date=August 13, 2017|access-date=August 13, 2017}}</ref> Trump did not expressly mention Neo-Nazis, [[white supremacy|white supremacists]], the [[alt-right]] movement, or counter protesters in his remarks.<ref name=":20">{{Cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/08/12/politics/trump-statement-alt-right-protests/index.html|title=Trump condemns 'hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides' in Charlottesville|last=CNN |first=Dan Merica|website=CNN|access-date=August 13, 2017}}</ref> Whereas Republican and Democratic elected officials condemned the violence and hatred of white nationalists, neo-Nazis and alt-right activists, ''The New York Times'' noted that Trump "was the only national political figure to spread blame for the "hatred, bigotry and violence" that resulted in the death of one person to 'many sides{{' "}}.<ref name="nyt2017" /> Two days later, Trump condemned "the KKK, neo-Nazis, white supremacists, and other hate groups".<ref>{{cite news|title=Trump decries KKK, neo-Nazi violence in Charlottesville|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/08/trump-decries-kkk-neo-nazi-violence-charlottesville-170814194807356.html|date=August 14, 2017|accessdate=August 15, 2017|publisher=Al Jazeera}}</ref> Then the next day, he returned to his initial comments, blaming "both sides".<ref name="NYT-20170815">{{cite news |last1=Shear |first1=Michael D. |last2=Haberman |first2=Maggie |title=Trump Defends Initial Remarks on Charlottesville; Again Blames 'Both Sides' |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/15/us/politics/trump-press-conference-charlottesville.html |date=August 15, 2017 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=August 15, 2017 }}</ref> Trump came under criticism from world leaders<ref>{{cite web|last1=TOOSI|first1=NAHAL|title=World leaders condemn Trump's remarks on neo-Nazis|url=http://www.politico.eu/article/world-leaders-condemn-trumps-remarks-on-neo-nazis/|publisher=Politico|accessdate=17 August 2017|date=August 16, 2017}}</ref> and politicians,<ref name="nyt2017">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/12/us/trump-charlottesville-protest-nationalist-riot.html|title=Trump's Remarks on Charlottesville Violence Are Criticized as Insufficient|last=Thrush|first=Glenn|date=August 12, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=August 13, 2017|last2=Haberman|first2=Maggie|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref name=":20" /> as well as a variety of religious groups<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pink|first1=Aiden|title=Orthodox Rabbinical Group Condemns Trump Over Charlottesville|url=http://forward.com/fast-forward/380204/orthodox-rabbinical-group-condemns-trump-over-charlottesville/|publisher=The Forward|accessdate=17 August 2017|date=August 16, 2017}}</ref> and anti-hate organizations<ref>{{cite web|title=ADL Condemns President Trump's Remarks|url=https://www.adl.org/news/press-releases/adl-condemns-president-trumps-remarks|publisher=ADL|accessdate=17 August 2017|date=August 15, 2017}}</ref> for his remarks, which were seen as muted and equivocal.<ref name="nyt2017" />
==Rights of the accused== In a 1989 interview with [[Larry King]], Trump stated: "The problem with our society is the victim has absolutely no rights and the criminal has unbelievable rights" and that "maybe hate is what we need if we're gonna get something done."<ref>[[Andrew Kaczynski]] & Jon Sarlin, [http://www.cnn.com/2016/10/07/politics/trump-larry-king-central-park-five/ Trump in 1989 Central Park Five interview: "Maybe hate is what we need"], CNN (October 10, 2016).</ref>
In 2016, Trump decried the fact that [[Ahmad Khan Rahami]], a U.S. citizen charged in connection with the [[2016 New York and New Jersey bombings|bombings in New York and New Jersey]], would be provided with medical treatment and the [[right to counsel]], calling this "sad."<ref>Jessica Taylor, [https://www.npr.org/2016/09/19/494633030/trump-calls-it-sad-that-n-y-bombing-suspect-gets-medical-care-lawyer Trump: 'Sad' N.Y. Bombing Suspect Gets Quality Medical Care, Lawyer], NPR (September 19, 2016).</ref><ref>Eric Boehm, [http://reason.com/blog/2016/09/20/donald-trump-vs-the-sixth-amendment Donald Trump Vs. The Sixth Amendment], ''Reason'' (September 20, 2016).</ref>
At the second presidential debate, which took place in October 2016, Trump said that if he was "in charge of the law of our country," rival presidential contender [[Hillary Clinton]] would "be in jail."<ref name="MorganMook">David Morgan, [http://www.cbsnews.com/news/clinton-campaign-manager-robby-mook-trump-thinks-u-s-is-banana-republic/ Clinton campaign manager likens Trump to a dictator], CBS News (October 10, 2016).</ref> In the same debate, Trump also pledged that if elected, he would direct his attorney general to appoint a [[special prosecutor]] to "look into" Clinton.<ref name="MorganMook"/> Clinton campaign manager [[Robby Mook]] called the remark "chilling" and said: "Trump thinks that the presidency is like some [[banana republic]] dictatorship where you can lock up your political opponents."<ref name="MorganMook"/> The remark was viewed as part of "a litany of statements [Trump] has made during the campaign that many legal specialists have portrayed as a threat to the rule of law."<ref name="SavageTinPot">Charlie Savage, [https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/11/us/politics/donald-trump-hillary-clinton-special-prosecutor.html Threat to Jail Clinton Smacks of 'Tin-Pot Dictators,' Experts Say], ''New York Times'' (October 10, 2016).</ref> The remark was condemned by a number of prominent Republican lawyers, such as [[Paul K. Charlton]], Marc Jimenez, and [[Peter Zeidenberg]],<ref name="Gerstein">Josh Gerstein, [http://www.politico.com/story/2016/10/trump-clinton-jail-ex-prosecutors-slam-229547 GOP ex-prosecutors slam Trump over threat to 'jail' Clinton], ''Politico'' (October 10, 2016).</ref> as well as [[David B. Rivkin]] and [[Michael Chertoff]].<ref name="SavageTinPot"/> Trump campaign manager [[Kellyanne Conway]] said that the "jail" comment was merely "a quip."<ref name="Gerstein"/>
Later that October, Trump spoke fondly of the "Lock her up" chants at his rally, saying "Lock her up is right."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/video/politics/trump-on-clinton-lock-her-up-is-right/2016/10/10/fd56d59e-8f51-11e6-bc00-1a9756d4111b_video.html|title=Trump on Clinton: 'Lock her up is right'|website=Washington Post|accessdate=October 12, 2016}}</ref> He also said that Clinton's legal representatives "have to go to jail".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/10/donald-trump-lashes-out-polls-media-gop-229691|title=Trump turns bitter|newspaper=POLITICO|accessdate=October 12, 2016}}</ref> However, in November, after winning the election, Trump told reporters from the ''[[New York Times]]'' that he would not recommend prosecution of Clinton, saying that it was "just not something (he) feel(s) very strongly about" and suggesting that Clinton had "suffered greatly".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/11/22/politics/conway-no-clinton-charges-donald-trump/ |title=Trump flips, now opposes prosecution for Clinton |last=Wright |first=David |last2=Wolf |first2=Z. Byron |date=23 November 2016|website=[[cnn.com]]|access-date=24 December 2016}}</ref> He repeated this stance in public at a rally in Michigan the following month, responding to "Lock her up" chants from the crowd by saying: "That plays great before the election - now we don't care, right?".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/12/09/politics/donald-trump-hillary-clinton-lock-her-up-chant/ |title=Trump on 'lock her up' chant: 'Now we don't care' |last=Diaz |first=Daniella |date=10 December 2016 |website=[[cnn.com]] |access-date=24 December 2016}}</ref>
===Trying U.S. citizens in military tribunals=== In August 2016, Trump said that he "would be fine" with trying [[U.S. citizens]] accused of terrorism in [[military tribunal]]s at the [[Guantanamo Bay Naval Base]] at [[Guantánamo Bay]], Cuba.<ref name="MazzeiGitmoUSCitizen">{{Cite web|author=Patricia Mazzei|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/politics-government/election/donald-trump/article95144337.html|title=Trump: Americans could be tried in Guantánamo|newspaper=Miami Herald|date=August 12, 2016}}</ref> Under current federal law (specifically, the [[Military Commissions Act of 2006]]), trying U.S. citizens at military commissions is illegal; only "alien unlawful enemy combatants" may be tried in such commissions.<ref name="MazzeiGitmoUSCitizen" /><ref>Quinta Jurecic, [https://www.lawfareblog.com/legality-donald-trumps-proposal-try-us-citizens-military-commission The Legality of Donald Trump's Proposal to Try US Citizens by Military Commission], ''Lawfare'' (August 12, 2016).</ref>
===Use of torture to procure information===
In February 2016, Trump said that he approved of the use of [[waterboarding]] and "a hell of a lot worse."<ref name="theguardian.com"/> He said that "[[torture]] works" and called waterboarding a "minor form" of torture. Speaking with [[Sean Hannity]] on [[Fox News]] on January 26, 2017, Trump termed waterboarding "just short of torture," and said, "I will tell you, though, it works. And I just spoke to people who told me it worked, and that's what they do." However, he said that he would rely on the advice of his defense secretary, [[James Mattis]] and others and, "If they don't wanna do, that's fine. If they do wanna do, then I will work for that end." <ref name="Fact Check.org">{{Cite web |url=http://www.factcheck.org/2017/01/trump-on-torture-again/ |title=Trump on Torture, Again |last=Schipani |first=Vanessa |date=January 27, 2017}}Trump discusses torture issue</ref>
==Voter fraud, voter ID laws, and false claims about "rigged elections"== Trump opposes same-day voter registration, supports voter identification laws, asserted that Obama won in 2012 due to voter fraud, has charged that the election system would be rigged against him in the 2016 race, and has equivocated on whether he would accept the outcome of the 2016 election.
Trump has asserted that America's "voting system is out of control," alleging that "you have people, in my opinion, that are voting many, many times," even though the number of cases of [[voter fraud]] in the U.S. is minuscule.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jenna Johnson|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/01/05/trump-alleges-widespread-voter-fraud-this-voting-system-is-out-of-control/|title=Trump alleges widespread voter fraud: 'This voting system is out of control.'|newspaper=Washington Post|accessdate=June 15, 2016}}</ref> Trump opposes [[same-day voter registration]], alleging that this allows non-citizens to vote in U.S. elections and that voting laws should prevent people from "[sneaking] in through the cracks."<ref name="CarrollVoting">{{cite web|author=Lauren Carroll|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2016/may/08/donald-trump/donald-trump-wrongly-says-noncitizens-can-vote-whe/|title=Donald Trump wrongly says non-citizens can vote when there is same-day voter registration|website=PolitiFact|date=May 8, 2016}}</ref> PolitiFact ruled Trump's claim about voter fraud false, noting that according to experts, "there is no additional risk of noncitizens casting ballots in states with same-day voter registration, nor is there any evidence that this occurs."<ref name="CarrollVoting"/>
While he has repeatedly charged during his candidacy that the election system is rigged against him, Trump's statements became bolder and more specific in August 2016.<ref name=":53">{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2016/08/12/trump-warns-of-electoral-cheating-during-pennsylvania-rally/|title=Trump Warns of Electoral 'Cheating' During Pennsylvania Rally|last=Routh|first=Julian|accessdate=August 13, 2016}}</ref> He alleged that the only way he would only lose Pennsylvania if "cheating goes on", and that voters will cast their ballots "15 times" for Clinton without [[Voter ID laws in the United States|voter ID laws]].<ref name=":53" /> ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' notes that several voter ID laws have been struck down in several states recently, with courts ruling that they unfairly discriminate against minority voters, and that "there is no evidence of widespread voter fraud occurring in recent U.S. elections."<ref name=":53" /> According to [[Dartmouth College|Dartmouth]] political scientist [[Brendan Nyhan]], Trump's rhetoric "threatens the norms of American elections and could provoke a damaging reaction among his supporters."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/06/upshot/how-donald-trumps-rigged-claim-chips-away-at-democracy.html|title=How Donald Trump's 'Rigged' Claim Chips Away at Democracy|last=Nyhan|first=Brendan|date=August 5, 2016|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|accessdate=August 13, 2016}}</ref>
In the September 2016 presidential debate, when asked if he would honor the outcome of the election, Trump said that he "absolutely" would.<ref name=":76">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/sep/30/trump-clinton-support-election-winner-debate-interview|title=Trump says he may not accept result if Clinton wins, in reversal from debate|last=Yuhas|first=Alan|date=September 30, 2016|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|accessdate=October 1, 2016}}</ref><ref name=":77">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/01/us/politics/donald-trump-interview-bill-hillary-clinton.html|title=Donald Trump Opens New Line of Attack on Hillary Clinton: Her Marriage|last=Healy|first=Patrick|date=September 30, 2016|last2=Haberman|first2=Maggie|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|accessdate=October 1, 2016}}</ref> Four days later, Trump appeared to have reconsidered his statement from the debate, saying "We're going to have to see. We're going to see what happens. We're going to have to see."<ref name=":76" /><ref name=":77" /> In early- and mid-October 2016, Trump repeatedly claimed that the election was "rigged" and alleged that the media coordinated with the Clinton campaign, citing Alec Baldwin's [[Saturday Night Live cast members#President of the United States impressionists|portrayal]] of him on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''.<ref name="SNL">{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2016/10/16/donald-trump-twitter-hillary-clinton-rigged-election/92194034/|title=Trump bashes 'rigged' election (and Saturday Night Live)|newspaper=USA Today|accessdate=October 16, 2016}}</ref> In October 2016, after early voting and voting by mail had begun in many states, Trump claimed, without evidence, that ""The election is absolutely being rigged" at "many polling places."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-rigged-idUSKBN12G0SU|title=Trump says election being rigged 'at many polling places'|date=October 16, 2016|agency=Reuters|accessdate=October 16, 2016}}</ref><ref name="SNL"/> That same month, Trump asserted, also without evidence, that the federal government was allowing illegal immigrants to come into the U.S. so they can vote.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/10/trump-immigrants-pouring-over-border-to-vote-229274|title=Trump says illegal immigrants pouring across the border to vote|newspaper=POLITICO|accessdate=October 7, 2016}}</ref> ''PolitiFact'' found Trump's claim of "large scale voter fraud" false, giving it a "Pants-on-fire" rating.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2016/oct/17/donald-trump/donald-trumps-pants-fire-claim-large-scale-voter-f/|title=Trump's Pants on Fire claim of 'large scale voter fraud'|newspaper=@politifact|accessdate=October 17, 2016}}</ref>
Trump has claimed that "dead people voted for President Obama" and that "dead voters... helped get President Obama elected."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/donald-trump-rigged-election-claims-172334896.html|title=Trump has long been making wild claims about election fraud|access-date=2017-02-15|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/nbcblk/here-are-allegations-trump-has-made-against-obama-clinton-n631746|title=Here Are The Allegations Trump Has Made Against Obama, Clinton|newspaper=NBC News|access-date=2017-02-15|language=en}}</ref> and alleged that voting machines were "switching" votes for the Republican nominee, [[Mitt Romney]], to votes for Obama.<ref name="Krieg">{{cite news|last1=Krieg|first1=Gregory|title=Sound familiar? Trump called 2012 vote a 'total sham'|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/10/18/politics/donald-trump-rigged-vote-twitter-2012/index.html|work=CNN|date=October 20, 2016}}</ref> On election night 2012, Trump expressed skepticism about Obama's victory, saying, among other things, "This election is a total sham and a travesty. We are not a democracy!"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/us-election/9661933/Donald-Trump-in-astonishing-Twitter-rant-after-Barack-Obama-wins-US-election.html|title=Donald Trump in astonishing Twitter rant after Barack Obama wins US election|accessdate=June 26, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/11/07/donald-trump-election-revolution_n_2085864.html|title=Trump: It's A 'Total Sham,' Time For 'Revolution'|last=Nick Wing Senior Viral Editor|first=The Huffington Post|date=November 7, 2012|website=The Huffington Post|accessdate=June 26, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2015/09/22/media/brian-williams-donald-trump/index.html|title=Who isn't happy to see Brian Williams again? Donald Trump|last=Kludt|first=Tom|date=September 22, 2015|website=CNNMoney|accessdate=June 27, 2016}}</ref> Additionally, when it seemed like [[Mitt Romney]] may have gained the popular vote but lost the electoral college vote, Trump called the electoral college system "a disaster for democracy",<ref>{{cite news|last1=News|first1=A. B. C.|title=Donald Trump 2012 Election Tweetstorm Resurfaces|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/donald-trumps-2012-election-tweetstorm-resurfaces-popular-electoral/story?id=43431536|work=ABC News|date=November 10, 2016}}</ref> calling for "a revolution in this country".<ref name="Krieg" /><ref>{{cite news|last1=Vincent|first1=James|title=Trump complains about 'unfair' protestors, deletes his tweets calling for revolution in 2012|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/11/11/13596932/trump-protestors-electoral-college-tweets|work=The Verge|date=November 11, 2016}}</ref>
Since his election in November 2016—in which he won the electoral college but received 2.8 million fewer votes nationally than Clinton—Trump has repeatedly insisted, without evidence, that he actually won the popular vote if one excludes "3 to 5 million illegal votes" cast for his opponent.<ref name="PhillipDeBonis">{{cite news|authors=Abby Phillip & Mike DeBonis|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2017/01/23/at-white-house-trump-tells-congressional-leaders-3-5-million-illegal-ballots-cost-him-the-popular-vote/|title=Without evidence, Trump tells lawmakers 3 million to 5 million illegal ballots cost him the popular vote|date=January 23, 2017|work=Washington Post}}</ref><ref name="StokolsClaim">{{cite news|author=Eli Stokols|title=Trump brings up vote fraud again, this time in meeting with senators|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/02/trump-voter-fraud-senators-meeting-234909|newspaper=Politico|date=February 10, 2017}}</ref> This claim is false.<ref>{{cite news|author=Michael D. Shear & Peter Baker|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/23/us/politics/donald-trump-congress-democrats.html|title=Trump Repeats Lie About Popular Vote in Meeting With Lawmakers|newspaper=New York Times|date=January 23, 2017}}</ref> After taking office, Trump said he would launch a major investigation into these unsubstantiated allegations, and appointing his Vice President, Mike Pence, to head a White House commission to do so.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/president-donald-trump-says-he-will-ask-major-investigation-allegations-n711956|title=President Trump Says He Will Ask for 'Major Investigation' Into Unsubstantiated Allegations of Voter Fraud|last=Silva|first=Daniella|date=January 25, 2017|publisher=NBC News}}</ref><ref name="Flores">{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/president-donald-trump-says-he-will-ask-major-investigation-allegations-n711956|title=President Trump Says He Will Ask for 'Major Investigation' Into Unsubstantiated Allegations of Voter Fraud|author=Reena Flores|date=February 5, 2017|publisher=CBS News}}</ref> Trump eventually followed through with that promise, announcing the creation of a commission to investigate voter fraud via an executive order on May 11, 2017.<ref>{{cite news|last1=[[White House Office of the Press Secretary|Office of the Press Secretary]]|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/05/11/presidential-executive-order-establishment-presidential-advisory|title=Presidential Executive Order on the Establishment of Presidential Advisory Commission on Election Integrity|work=[[whitehouse.gov]]|publisher=[[White House]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|date=May 11, 2017|accessdate=August 18, 2017}}</ref> On June 29, 2017, the vice-chairman of Trump's voter fraud commission, former [[Secretary of State of Kansas|Kansas Secretary of State]] [[Kris Kobach]], instructed the [[Secretary of state (U.S. state government)|secretaries of state]] for all [[List of states and territories of the United States|50 states]] to provide the commission with voter roll data, though most refused to provide some voter information, citing concerns of privacy. This prompted President Trump to remark on Twitter, "Numerous states are refusing to give information to the very distinguished VOTER FRAUD PANEL. What are they trying to hide?".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/340117-trump-election-integrity-commission-requests-years-of-voter-data-from|title=Trump election panel asks all 50 states for voter roll data|last=Carter|first=Brandon|date=June 29, 2017|accessdate=August 18, 2017|publisher=The Hill}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/07/03/politics/kris-kobach-letter-voter-fraud-commission-information/index.html|title=Forty-four states and DC have refused to give certain voter information to Trump commission|last=Hauck|first=Grace|last2=Stark|first2=Liz|date=July 5, 2017|accessdate=August 18, 2017|publisher=CNN}}</ref>
==Women in the military== In 2013, Trump questioned the wisdom of allowing women to serve, linking gender-integrated forces with higher rates of sexual assault "26,000 unreported sexual assaults in the military-only 238 convictions. What did these geniuses expect when they put men & women together?"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/331909758028222466|title=Donald J. Trump on Twitter|website=Twitter|accessdate=June 21, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/331907383771148288|title=Donald J. Trump on Twitter|website=Twitter|accessdate=June 21, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/26/us/politics/donald-trump-women.html|title=Donald Trump's Trail of Comments About Women|last=Rappeport|first=Alan|date=March 25, 2016|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|accessdate=June 22, 2016}}</ref><ref name=":33">{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/natemcdermott/trump-in-2014-on-women-in-the-army-it-is-bedlam|title=Trump In 2014 On Women In The Army: "It Is Bedlam"|website=BuzzFeed|accessdate=June 22, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/politics/donald-trump-sexism-tracker-every-offensive-comment-in-one-place/|title=Donald Trump sexism tracker: Every offensive comment in one place|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=June 22, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/08/donald-trump-tweet-sexual-assault-military_n_3239781.html|title=Go Home, Donald|last=Media|first=The Editors HuffPost|date=May 8, 2013|website=The Huffington Post|accessdate=June 22, 2016}}</ref> In 2014, Trump stated that it was "bedlam" to bring women into the army.<ref name=":33" /> In August 2015, Trump said he would support [[Women in the military in the Americas|women in combat roles]] "because they're really into it and some of them are really, really good."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/videos/politics/2015/08/19/trump-on-women-in-the-military.cnn|title=Trump on women in military: 'Yes, because they're really into it' - CNN Video|website=CNN|accessdate=June 21, 2016}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Steve Allin | image = <!-- filename only, no "File:" or "Image:" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = 1955 | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then | death_place = --> | nationality = British | other_names = | occupation = author and hemp consultant | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = Author of ''Building with Hemp'', founder of the [[International Hemp Building Association]] }}
'''Steve Allin''' (born 1955) is an author, teacher and pioneer in the use of [[hemp]] in construction and director of the [[International Hemp Building Association]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hilton|first1=Lindsay|title=Bellingham hemp advocate hopes to change the way we build|url=http://www.bellinghamherald.com/living/seniors-aging/article61978802.html|work=The Bellingham Herald|date=2016-03-08}}</ref>
Allin begun using [[Hempcrete|hemp]] and lime as a natural construction material in 1997 which led him to write and published Building with Hemp in 2005,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Prietnitz|first1=Rolf B.|title=Hemp For Houses|url=http://www.life.ca/naturallife/0604/hemphouse.htm|website=Natural Life Magazine|date=2006}}</ref> the first published book on using hemp as a building system. He has contributed to The Green Building Bible and Local Sustainable Homes and has written articles for magazines Self-Build,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Allin|first1=Steve|title=Hemp: the answer to zero carbon homes?|publisher=Selfbuild and Improve Magazine|edition=Spring 2015}}</ref> [[Cannabis Culture]],<ref>{{cite book|title=Building with Cannabis|date=2006|publisher=Cannabis Culture Magazine|page=72|edition=issue 63}}</ref> Construct Ireland, Energy Blitz,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Allin|first1=Steve|title=Hemp - A really ecological building material for India|date=2012|publisher=Energy Blitz Magazine}}</ref> Hanf and New Observations Magazine. He founded the [[International Hemp Building Association]] in 2009, after hosting a symposium on the subject in [[Kenmare]], Ireland.
He advocates the use of hemp as a construction material for it’s ecological production and low carbon footprint both as a material and the subsequent use, energy wise of the structure in a sustainable way<ref>{{cite news|last1=Harrison|first1=Bernice|title=Why hemp is hot stuff|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/life-and-style/homes-and-property/why-hemp-is-hot-stuff-1.1309217|work=The Irish Times|date=2004-04-22}}</ref> and has stated.
{{Quote|text=Across the world communities and political leaders are grappling with the major issues of economy, employment and uncertain changing weather... So what are we all going to do about it? Kick the can down the road another piece?...An industrial crop is being identified as being able to provide many of the solutions to these aspects of our society but can a plant really do that? What on earth are these people talking about? Of course the plant we are talking about is hemp, an annual crop that can be grown in just about every country on the planet and probably has been.|author=Steve Allin|title=''Can Hemp Really Be The Answer?''|source=New Observations Art & Culture, 2017}}
Allin introduced hemp building to the US after holding a course in Prescott, Wisconsin in 2012.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hudson|first1=Bill|title=Company Uses Hemp To Help Build Homes, Despite Costly Regulations|url=http://minnesota.cbslocal.com/2012/06/12/company-uses-hemp-to-help-build-homes-despite-regulations/|work=CBS Minnesota|date=2012-06-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Martell|first1=Sherry|title=First hemp house in Atlantic Canada under construction in The Falls|url=http://www.trurodaily.com/news/local/2013/7/26/first-hemp-house-in-atlantic-canada-unde-3329311.html|work=Truro Daily News|date=2013-07-26}}</ref> In 2013 he introduced the system to Finland when he held a course in Turku<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ruuska|first1=Vesa-Matti|title=Kouluttaja: Hamppuseinä sopii myös Suomeen|url=https://yle.fi/uutiset/3-6689085|work=Yle Uutiset|date=2013-06-15}}</ref> and then in Sweden in Kristianstad.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ten Skåne start-ups to watch in 2015|url=https://www.thelocal.se/20141009/the-top-ten-start-ups-from-skane-tlccu|work=The Local SE|date=2014-10-09}}</ref> He also introduced hemp building to Nepal in 2015, demonstrating the system for part of a hospital in Janakpur and again in 2017 to Costa Rica, teaching a workshop in Flamingo, Guanacaste.<ref>{{cite news|title=Así se construye la primera casa con cáñamo en Costa Rica.|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LzLky1PC8Hc|work=Medical Cannabis News MCN|date=2017-05-22}}</ref> He is currently involved in projects to rebuild with hemp in the post-earthquake areas of [[Haiti]] and Nepal<ref>{{cite news|title=Globetripper: The HempToday Interview|url=https://hemptoday.net/steve-allins-hemp-world/|work=HempToday|date=2016-10-05}}</ref> and is a senior adviser at HempToday magazine.<ref>{{cite book|title=15 Euro Hemp Leaders|date=2017|publisher=HempToday|page=8|edition=HempToday/EIHA Special|url=https://hemptoday.net/shop/eiha-2017-special-edition/}}</ref>
==Books== * Allin, Steve (2005). Building with Hemp. SeedPress. {{ISBN|978-0-9551109-0-0}}. * Allin, Steve (2012). Building with Hemp 2nd Edition. SeedPress. {{ISBN|978-0-9551109-1-7}}. * Allin, Steve (2016). Hemp Can’t Save The Planet BUT It Might Save Humanity! {{ISBN|978-0-9551109-6-2}}.
==Contributor==
* Hall, Keith. (2006). The Green Building Bible, Volume 1 [Paperback] Green Building Press. {{ISBN|978-1-8981300-3-1}}. * Bird, Chris. (2010). Local Sustainable Homes. Transition Books. {{ISBN|978-1-900322-76-8}}. * Allin, Steve; Anthony Cohu (2016). Hemp Building Best Practice Guide. {{ISBN|978-0-9551109-4-8}}.
==See also==
